commit_message:
Introduce os_congress role in gerrit

This commit makes possible to contribute to the os_congress role.
It ensures the roles follows the minimum testing, in order to
be improved later with further testing.

The minimum testing is a local API test that's currently not
passing and will be improved by the community.

Co-Authored-By: Taseer Ahmed <taseer94@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Jesse Pretorius <jesse.pretorius@rackspace.co.uk>
Change-Id: Iffe98a040b93b1101fe3339edc84d6197e5a5da7

commit_message:
use EGRESS_DIRECTION and INGRESS_DIRECTION from neutron-lib

The EGRESS_DIRECTION and INGRESS_DIRECTION constants live in neutron-lib
now and neutron is going to consume them in
I1b81f5c3de9e6f2c0967c2db23ddb716ee7ec6b9

This patch removes the EGRESS_DIRECTION, INGRESS_DIRECTION and
VALID_DIRECTIONS constants from common.constants as they are already
defined and use from neutron-lib.

Change-Id: I52841ecd716f6dbf87fc4c5543d68ba378edbeea

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-13 21:32:24.000000000', 'message': 'Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: Ifba72d3ff0dbaa3a9ae3b7e420fc7642e4b4edee
'}]
commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: Ifba72d3ff0dbaa3a9ae3b7e420fc7642e4b4edee

[{'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2018-02-12 16:41:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-02-12 17:01:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2018-02-12 17:15:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-02-12 17:20:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

before reverting, I would try to go with https://review.openstack.org/#/c/543536/ or https://review.openstack.org/543552

If none of them works, then ok for reverting.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-02-12 23:49:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/543536/ fix it'}, {'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2018-02-13 07:47:37.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-02-13 14:40:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

please note that example patch https://review.openstack.org/#/c/543861/ is running the subject change in check jobs and looks quite green. Minor/major upgrades jobs failures are prolly unrelated as they look redish for quite a long. How can we define revert criterion w/o a proper coverage in CI jobs?'}, {'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2018-02-13 15:13:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@Bogdan, the same thing we thought yesterday, when fixing jobs. That's the problem with such patches, you continue to discover problems and it doesn't finish. commit_message:
add segments service_plugin to neutron-api

* adds a service_plugin called segments to enable routed provider
networks
* adds a nova placement api section and inclusion of that section to
neutron.conf
* routed provider networks can be used for setups with and without
charm-neutron-gateway - in both cases there should be a dhcp agent per
segment which can be achieved via charm-neutron-openvswitch
configuration option enable-local-dhcp-and-metadata in case of a setup
without charm-neutron-gateway

Change-Id: I78222b567c72c03ab2d861836172032d4d9a0b3f
Closes-Bug: 1743743

Change-Id: Icdb1b94b0e69ffb55007e166705871010e8943c5
(cherry picked from commit 66c03b53d929e8bf727c3e7c7a998b2ba114d4d5)

commit_message:
Use native v3 tox jobs

Instead of a legacy tox job, use the already defined functional jobs
that do the same. Note that those jobs are named "functional", so update
tox.ini as well.

Remove unused playbooks.

Resolved merge conflict with tox.ini/

Change-Id: Icdb1b94b0e69ffb55007e166705871010e8943c5
(cherry picked from commit 66c03b53d929e8bf727c3e7c7a998b2ba114d4d5)

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: Iadbdf1f9764f1b41cfff366a5f21e19156a7def8

commit_message:
Fix doc build warnings

Fix a couple of warnings that show up when tox -e docs is run.

Also, improve RST formatting and remove extra lines.

Treat warnings as errors to not have those come in again.

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-13 15:05:14.000000000', 'message': 'Fix overcloud export plan

Currently exporting the plan for the overcloud gives us (note the
spurious 3600 argument there):
(undercloud) [stack@undercloud t]$ openstack overcloud plan export overcloud
Exporting plan overcloud...
Started Mistral Workflow tripleo.plan_management.v1.export_deployment_plan. Execution ID: 19da7423-ff44-4785-9f1f-237289b60dda
Error while creating a tarball: Unexpected error while running command.
Command: /usr/bin/tar -C /tmp/tmpiBEE9d 3600 /tmp/tmpOST_qM --exclude .git --exclude .tox --exclude *.pyc --exclude *.pyo .
Exit code: 2
Stdout: u''
Stderr: u"/usr/bin/tar: You must specify one of the `-Acdtrux' or `--test-label' options\nTry `/usr/bin/tar --help' or `/usr/bin/tar --usage' for more information.\n"
Exception exporting plan: Error while creating a tarball: Unexpected error while running command.
Command: /usr/bin/tar -C /tmp/tmpiBEE9d 3600 /tmp/tmpOST_qM --exclude .git --exclude .tox --exclude *.pyc --exclude *.pyo .
Exit code: 2
Stdout: u''
Stderr: u"/usr/bin/tar: You must specify one of the `-Acdtrux' or `--test-label' options\nTry `/usr/bin/tar --help' or `/usr/bin/tar --usage' for more information.\n"

The reason is that in tripleo_common/actions/plan.py we call the
following:
swiftutils.create_and_upload_tarball(
  swift, tmp_dir, self.exports_container, tarball_name,
  self.delete_after)

The reason is that in
tripleo_common/utils/swift.py:create_and_upload_tarball() we added
'tarball_options' as an option but we did not add it at the end and we
had a caller using a positional argument.

Let's make sure that 'delete_after' is passed as a named argument.

Co-Authored-By: Damien Ciabrini <dciabrin@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Idda2f6da3d84d1c448d941c962a07616863d61bf
Closes-Bug: #1749204
'}]
commit_message:
Fix overcloud export plan

Currently exporting the plan for the overcloud gives us (note the
spurious 3600 argument there):
(undercloud) [stack@undercloud t]$ openstack overcloud plan export overcloud
Exporting plan overcloud...
Started Mistral Workflow tripleo.plan_management.v1.export_deployment_plan. Execution ID: 19da7423-ff44-4785-9f1f-237289b60dda
Error while creating a tarball: Unexpected error while running command.
Command: /usr/bin/tar -C /tmp/tmpiBEE9d 3600 /tmp/tmpOST_qM --exclude .git --exclude .tox --exclude *.pyc --exclude *.pyo .
Exit code: 2
Stdout: u''
Stderr: u"/usr/bin/tar: You must specify one of the `-Acdtrux' or `--test-label' options\nTry `/usr/bin/tar --help' or `/usr/bin/tar --usage' for more information.\n"
Exception exporting plan: Error while creating a tarball: Unexpected error while running command.
Command: /usr/bin/tar -C /tmp/tmpiBEE9d 3600 /tmp/tmpOST_qM --exclude .git --exclude .tox --exclude *.pyc --exclude *.pyo .
Exit code: 2
Stdout: u''
Stderr: u"/usr/bin/tar: You must specify one of the `-Acdtrux' or `--test-label' options\nTry `/usr/bin/tar --help' or `/usr/bin/tar --usage' for more information.\n"

The reason is that in tripleo_common/actions/plan.py we call the
following:
swiftutils.create_and_upload_tarball(
  swift, tmp_dir, self.exports_container, tarball_name,
  self.delete_after)

The reason is that in
tripleo_common/utils/swift.py:create_and_upload_tarball() we added
'tarball_options' as an option but we did not add it at the end and we
had a caller using a positional argument.

Let's make sure that 'delete_after' is passed as a named argument.

Co-Authored-By: Damien Ciabrini <dciabrin@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Idda2f6da3d84d1c448d941c962a07616863d61bf
Closes-Bug: #1749204

commit_message:
Add OpenStack-Ansible metadata

We need to add openstack ansible information in the role
metadata to be able to track role maturity. With it,
we can create a role maturity table and take decisions about
role deprecations.

Change-Id: I474ab6f9aea61415fdbfa8f05c4cc5158ff5e54e

commit_message:
Delete system role assignments when deleting groups

Keystone removes role assignments that groups have on projects and
domains when deleting groups. This should apply to system role
assignments, too.

Change-Id: Iebedfcae0b77e350e5359b97fa87894af3f1c8ba
Closes-Bug: 1749267

commit_message:
Expose bug in system assignment when deleting groups

Project and domain role assignment are cleaned up when deleting
groups. This commit introduces a test case that shows this isn't the
case for system role assignments. A subsequent patch will implement
a fix to make sure system role assignments are removed when groups
are deleted, to be consistent with project and domain assignments.

Change-Id: I9b452aff144fd8867cdac2f44cbcaa0d1de63a12
Partial-Bug: 1749267

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: Id4cbfc5e9abacf43831775c7538aa13e47ea3f8b

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-17 17:57:06.000000000', 'message': "l3_ha: only pass host into update_port when updating router port bindings

There is a race condition in update_routers_states that may result in
some fixed ips incorrectly deallocated from router ports. This may
happen if update_routers_states fetches ports' state before another
thread updates the list; then update_routers_states passes port payloads
with old fixed ips into update_port, which results in ip address
deallocation. Among other things, l3 agent will detect the change and
remove the affected subnet prefix from radvd configuration file, since
it doesn't configure extra_subnets for RA.

There is no need to pass full port payload into update_port just to set
host. This patch replaces the payload with a dict of one key - host.
This allows core plugin to handle just this host field change, leaving
existing allocations (and other port attributes) intact.

Conflicts:
      neutron/db/l3_hamode_db.py
      neutron/tests/unit/db/test_l3_hamode_db.py

Change-Id: Ib2c661d6e2cb8e34676fd83e19b6cf65c232545d
Closes-Bug: #1743658
(cherry picked from commit fea188acd173fe09e2e6f98534c4b9cb1523ebc6)
(cherry picked from commit 91f377cd2547c3633c5fcc386303d60fa0733c7f)

it doesn't configure extra_subnets for RA.

There is no need to pass full port payload into update_port just to set
host. This patch replaces the payload with a dict of one key - host.
This allows core plugin to handle just this host field change, leaving
existing allocations (and other port attributes) intact.

Conflicts:
      neutron/db/l3_hamode_db.py
      neutron/tests/unit/db/test_l3_hamode_db.py

Change-Id: Ib2c661d6e2cb8e34676fd83e19b6cf65c232545d

commit_message:
l3_ha: only pass host into update_port when updating router port bindings

There is a race condition in update_routers_states that may result in
some fixed ips incorrectly deallocated from router ports. This may
happen if update_routers_states fetches ports' state before another
thread updates the list; then update_routers_states passes port payloads
with old fixed ips into update_port, which results in ip address
deallocation. Among other things, l3 agent will detect the change and
remove the affected subnet prefix from radvd configuration file, since
it doesn't configure extra_subnets for RA.

There is no need to pass full port payload into update_port just to set
host. This patch replaces the payload with a dict of one key - host.
This allows core plugin to handle just this host field change, leaving
existing allocations (and other port attributes) intact.

Conflicts:
      neutron/db/l3_hamode_db.py
      neutron/tests/unit/db/test_l3_hamode_db.py

Change-Id: Ib2c661d6e2cb8e34676fd83e19b6cf65c232545d
Closes-Bug: #1743658
(cherry picked from commit fea188acd173fe09e2e6f98534c4b9cb1523ebc6)

subject: Update lower bound for openstacksdk to 0.11.2
messages:
[{'account_id': 2, 'date': '2018-02-02 11:16:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8246, 'date': '2018-02-02 14:06:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

No. It is too late to bump the lower bound. We'd better instead cap the upper-constraints and lift the constraints after queens release."}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2018-02-02 15:09:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yeah - the constraints is set already - so we should be good for the gate. It's not a super-big deal if we can't lower the bounds as well, just thought I'd toss it up and see what we thought."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-02-02 15:19:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> No. It is too late to bump the lower bound. We'd better instead cap
 > the upper-constraints and lift the constraints after queens
 > release.

If we're already constrained to the higher version what technical problem do you see in raising the minimum?"}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-02-02 16:29:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow-1 Code-Review-2

-2-W for freeze

It's a bit too late to do this without a very good reason, while bumping the min would be nice, it's the UC that we 'support'"}, {'account_id': 8246, 'date': '2018-02-03 01:11:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

We have seen too incompatible changes between the lower bound and the upper.

- the response object no longer has the headers attribute, this means we cannot extract the openstack-request-id header.
- the HttpException has removed 'http_status' field, and we need it to properly parse the exception."}, {'account_id': 8246, 'date': '2018-02-03 01:12:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Sorry, two changes noticed.  See this:
http://logs.openstack.org/20/540320/2/check/openstack-tox-py27/7e4d450/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-02-02_12_35_26_708781'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-02-03 01:16:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

did you make a ffe to the mailing list for this?  I'd probably be fine with it but we still need that ffe"}, {'account_id': 8246, 'date': '2018-02-03 01:40:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Matthew, thanks for the consideration.
I am not strongly opinionated towards the lower bound or the upper bound.
Given the incompatibility we found in functional tests, I'm more inclined to reset upper constraints to 0.9.19. If there is a compelling reason to raise the lower bound, I'm okay with it too. Just want to make sure we are not allowing this version range where things behave differently.

I'd prefer leaving the decision to Monty. He has spent a HUGE effort on SDK improvement. He knows better which version we should use. It was a big surprise to me that after all those changes, we only found two small issues. :)"}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-02-03 01:47:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

monty, can you respond?'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-02-14 03:45:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Workflow Code-Review+2

gr update'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-02-14 06:49:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2

Looks good to me.

Qimeng Teng's comment is correct for queens but we're on the Rocky Road"}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-02 11:16:51.000000000', 'message': 'Update lower bound for openstacksdk to 0.11.2

0.11.2 is needed by octavia-dashboard at least. It will also be great to
bump the lower bound in queens past the point where we introduce the new
merged shade/occ code so that updating consuming projects to use the new
interfaces can be done cleanly.

But the main driver is octavia-dashboard.

Change-Id: If9635118b5d6b5c794b1ebc2625b64c314e57155
'}]
commit_message:
Update lower bound for openstacksdk to 0.11.2

0.11.2 is needed by octavia-dashboard at least. It will also be great to
bump the lower bound in queens past the point where we introduce the new
merged shade/occ code so that updating consuming projects to use the new
interfaces can be done cleanly.

But the main driver is octavia-dashboard.

Change-Id: If9635118b5d6b5c794b1ebc2625b64c314e57155

With this change, a metric's dimensions are used instead of the measurement's
metadata for storage informations.

"}]
commit_message:
Use metric dimensions as metadata in monasca collector

With this change, a metric's dimensions are used instead of the measurement's
metadata for storage informations.

This allows the collector to provide more metadata and increases its performance
(less requests on the monasca API are made).

Change-Id: I1ecfe4929308718f9c448c5235634888dd456f3f

Yaml.load() return Python object may be dangerous if you receive a YAML

commit_message:
Replaces yaml.load() with yaml.safe_load()

Yaml.load() return Python object may be dangerous if you receive a YAML
document from an untrusted source such as the Internet. The function
yaml.safe_load() limits this ability to simple Python objects like integers or
lists.

Reference:
https://security.openstack.org/guidelines/dg_avoid-dangerous-input-parsing-libraries.html

Change-Id: Iab51ca23786bb18911cdb4dd640ce2726f63ca30

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-13 13:42:52.000000000', 'message': "Fixes devstack plugin script

The repo and path name is oswin-tempest-plugin, not
oswin_tempest_plugin. Because of this, Devstack fails if this plugin
is included in devstack's local.conf.

Change-Id: I3ea29fc0d9d7c3151c21728daf7345fbeb710b68
"}]
commit_message:
Fixes devstack plugin script

The repo and path name is oswin-tempest-plugin, not
oswin_tempest_plugin. Because of this, Devstack fails if this plugin
is included in devstack's local.conf.

Change-Id: I3ea29fc0d9d7c3151c21728daf7345fbeb710b68

@Vasyl
We are not using any external HTTP_SERVER, web server is installed on the same vm and HTTP_SERVER is getting populated through HOST_IP.'}, {'account_id': 19604, 'date': '2017-07-28 09:36:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

IRONIC_HTTP_SERVER is getting set through IRONIC_TFTPSERVER_IP
https://github.com/openstack/ironic/blob/master/devstack/lib/ironic#L391 that in turn getting set through HOST_IP https://github.com/openstack/ironic/blob/master/devstack/lib/ironic#L124. If someone want to use their own HTTP_SERVER, they can pass as IRONIC_HTTP_SERVER.'}, {'account_id': 14525, 'date': '2017-07-28 20:56:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

> IRONIC_HTTP_SERVER is getting set through IRONIC_TFTPSERVER_IP
 > https://github.com/openstack/ironic/blob/master/devstack/lib/ironic#L391
 > that in turn getting set through HOST_IP https://github.com/openstack/ironic/blob/master/devstack/lib/ironic#L124.
 > If someone want to use their own HTTP_SERVER, they can pass as
 > IRONIC_HTTP_SERVER.

I'm a bit confused as we will configure apache to listen on IRONIC_PORT only when ipxe is enabled https://github.com/openstack/ironic/blob/master/devstack/lib/ironic#L866"}, {'account_id': 11076, 'date': '2017-08-01 09:10:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Vasyl, We do run separate HTTP server using 'webfs'. We should ideally set the IRONIC_HTTP_SERVER in our conf.
We run this HTTP server on the same system where devstack is running. This makes the IRONIC_HTTP_SERVER to use HOST_IP settings. 
https://github.com/openstack/ironic/blob/master/devstack/lib/ironic#L124

Hi! We are starting migrating our tempest plugin to a separate repository - https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/ironic-tempest-plugin/ We expect the migration to be finished by Thursday, please re-propose your changes there. Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2017-12-20 11:07:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2017-12-20 23:09:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review-2

(1 comment)

Tempest tests are intended to verify the API contract and not specific features supported by a specific vendor driver. I think it is fine if a vendor has specific testing in their 3rd party CI, however vendor specific tests should not be in the collective public test set enforce the API contract.

Beyond that, we have moved tempest tests out of tree.'}, {'account_id': 19604, 'date': '2018-01-18 08:53:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(1 comment)

Thanks Julia for comment. Please find my response inline.'}, {'account_id': 19604, 'date': '2018-02-14 07:33:39.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

[{'created': '2017-04-13 06:35:13.000000000', 'message': "Add localhost api server URL to resourceUrlWhitelist

This commit adds localhost api server URL to resourceUrlWhitelist. When
we test openstack-health locally, we need to access to an api server
from Angular app. Recently, it is restricted by the Angular update. I
was thinking 'self' includes an api server like localhost:5000 but it
doesn't. And I also think this is enough for our testing in most of
cases.

Change-Id: Iec60b0c71222809dee0e44ec6c03f4371da07892
"}, {'created': '2017-04-13 13:06:01.000000000', 'message': "Add localhost api server URL to resourceUrlWhitelist

we test openstack-health locally, we need to access to an api server
from Angular app. Recently, it is restricted by the Angular update. I
was thinking 'self' includes an api server like localhost:5000 but it
doesn't. And I also think this is enough for our testing in most of

Change-Id: Iec60b0c71222809dee0e44ec6c03f4371da07892
"}]
commit_message:
Add localhost api server URL to resourceUrlWhitelist

This commit adds localhost api server URL to resourceUrlWhitelist. When
we test openstack-health locally, we need to access to an api server
from Angular app. Recently, it is restricted by the Angular update. I
was thinking 'self' includes an api server like localhost:5000 but it
doesn't. And I also think this is enough for our testing in most of
cases.

Change-Id: Iec60b0c71222809dee0e44ec6c03f4371da07892

commit_message:
Avoid networkx 2.0

networkx 2.0 has released but is not backwards compatible with 1.0.
Avoid it for now.

Partial-Bug: #1718576
Change-Id: If394af569790b38106fd4cb18266ef0300703e87

When helm crashes/fails it can leave tmpcharts directories behind;
update the 'clean' target to remove these.

Change-Id: Ib0fb6e93262fbc6fd97dfdd491df46283dff4a9e
"}]
commit_message:
Makefile: cleanup after helm

When helm crashes/fails it can leave tmpcharts directories behind;
update the 'clean' target to remove these.

Change-Id: Ib0fb6e93262fbc6fd97dfdd491df46283dff4a9e

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-28 22:14:41.000000000', 'message': "Grant admin a role on the system during bootstrap

Now that we have system scope in place, we should make sure at least
one user has a role assignment on the system. We can do this at the
same time we grant the user a role on a project during bootstrap.

This is backwards compatible because even if a deployment doesn't use
system-scope, the assignment will just sit there. The deployment will
have to opt into enforcing scope by updating configuration options
for oslo.policy to enforce scoping.

This shouldn't prevent deployments from fixing bug 968696 and using
system scope.

bp system-scope

Change-Id: I6b7196a28867d9a699716c8fef2609d608a5b2a2

commit_message:
Grant admin a role on the system during bootstrap

Now that we have system scope in place, we should make sure at least
one user has a role assignment on the system. We can do this at the
same time we grant the user a role on a project during bootstrap.

This is backwards compatible because even if a deployment doesn't use
system-scope, the assignment will just sit there. The deployment will
have to opt into enforcing scope by updating configuration options
for oslo.policy to enforce scoping.

This shouldn't prevent deployments from fixing bug 968696 and using
system scope.

Closes-Bug: 1749268

Change-Id: I6b7196a28867d9a699716c8fef2609d608a5b2a2

commit_message:
Fix querying role_assignment with system roles

This commit removes system role assignments when querying keystone
for a list of assignments pertaining to a specific role. For example,
`GET /v3/role_assignments?role.id={role_id}`, now returns assignments
only for that role. Previously, the list contained false positives
because some system role assignments weren't being removed. This
was introduced in queens with the system scope work.

Change-Id: Iab35ae01bb715da5813e62cd09900de555dceaaa
Closes-Bug: 1748970

subject: Expose bug in /role_assignments API with system-scope
messages: [{'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-02-13 17:17:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-02-13 17:31:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-02-13 19:20:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-02-13 20:01:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2018-02-14 01:20:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2018-02-14 04:53:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-13 17:17:59.000000000', 'message': 'Expose bug in /role_assignments API with system-scope

The role_assignment API supports a bunch of query parameters that
gives users flexibility when querying for role assignments. This
commit exposes an issue when querying keystone for a specific role
using /role_assignments?role.id={role_id}. The expected result was
that the returned list would only contain role assignments for that
specific role ID. The actual result is a set of role assignments with
that role ID and all system role assignments.

This caused issues in tempest because tempest goes through and cleans
up resources using `tearDownClass`, and it is common to remove
specific roles used in the test class. The problem is that keystone
queries the role assignment API for all role assignment with a
specific role ID, which is the equivalent to
`GET /v3/role_assignments?role.id={role_id}` when deleting a role. The
list returned included false positives, which were system role
assignments, resulting in revocation events getting persisted for
users in those role assignments. This prevented the administrator in
tempest from cleaning up the rest of the resources because the
revocation event would make the token being used to do resource
cleanup.

This commit exposes the bug using tests.

Change-Id: If93400be3c9d3fe8e266bb36c16accca93d77154
Partial-Bug: 1748970
'}, {'created': '2018-02-13 19:20:09.000000000', 'message': 'Expose bug in /role_assignments API with system-scope

The role_assignment API supports a bunch of query parameters that
gives users flexibility when querying for role assignments. This
commit exposes an issue when querying keystone for a specific role
using /role_assignments?role.id={role_id}. The expected result was
that the returned list would only contain role assignments for that
specific role ID. The actual result is a set of role assignments with
that role ID and all system role assignments.

This caused issues in tempest because tempest goes through and cleans
up resources using `tearDownClass`, and it is common to remove
specific roles used in the test class. The problem is that keystone
queries the role assignment API for all role assignment with a
specific role ID, which is the equivalent to
`GET /v3/role_assignments?role.id={role_id}` when deleting a role. The
list returned included false positives, which were system role
assignments, resulting in revocation events getting persisted for
users in those role assignments. This prevented the administrator in
tempest from cleaning up the rest of the resources because the
revocation event would make the token being used to do resource
cleanup.

This commit exposes the bug using tests.

Change-Id: If93400be3c9d3fe8e266bb36c16accca93d77154
Partial-Bug: 1748970
'}]
commit_message:
Expose bug in /role_assignments API with system-scope

The role_assignment API supports a bunch of query parameters that
gives users flexibility when querying for role assignments. This
commit exposes an issue when querying keystone for a specific role
using /role_assignments?role.id={role_id}. The expected result was
that the returned list would only contain role assignments for that
specific role ID. The actual result is a set of role assignments with
that role ID and all system role assignments.

This caused issues in tempest because tempest goes through and cleans
up resources using `tearDownClass`, and it is common to remove
specific roles used in the test class. The problem is that keystone
queries the role assignment API for all role assignment with a
specific role ID, which is the equivalent to
`GET /v3/role_assignments?role.id={role_id}` when deleting a role. The
list returned included false positives, which were system role
assignments, resulting in revocation events getting persisted for
users in those role assignments. This prevented the administrator in
tempest from cleaning up the rest of the resources because the
revocation event would make the token being used to do resource
cleanup.

This commit exposes the bug using tests.

Change-Id: If93400be3c9d3fe8e266bb36c16accca93d77154
Partial-Bug: 1748970

[{'created': '2018-02-13 10:01:15.000000000', 'message': 'Fix html_last_updated_fmt for Python3

html_last_updated_fmt option is interpreted as a
byte string in python3, causing Sphinx build to break.
This patch makes it utf-8 string.

Change-Id: I7258191f4376547b5693e88191e8cd799566966b
Closes-Bug:#1693670

commit_message:
Fix html_last_updated_fmt for Python3

html_last_updated_fmt option is interpreted as a
byte string in python3, causing Sphinx build to break.
This patch makes it utf-8 string.

Change-Id: I7258191f4376547b5693e88191e8cd799566966b
Closes-Bug:#1693670

The tag and tag_ext extensions are deprecated for removal, but are not
used today [1]. Rather than rehoming these extensions to neutron-lib and

commit_message:
remove tag and tag_ext extensions

The tag and tag_ext extensions are deprecated for removal, but are not
used today [1]. Rather than rehoming these extensions to neutron-lib and
carrying out their deprecation life-cycle for no apparent reason, this
patch proposes we just remove them now.

[1] http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=from%20neutron.extensions%20import%20(tag_ext%7Ctag)

Change-Id: I0d7bcd789b468b1dd3f7ea13e6751a46203d6778

fast_forward_upgrade_playbook.yaml

This is the top level playbook controlling the upgrade. This contains a single
fast forward upgrade play that acts as the outer loop providing the release via
FastForwardUpgradeReleases to the underlying tasks.

fast_forward_upgrade_step_tasks.yaml

This file contains a single include task and is simply used to control the
inner loop providing the step to the underlying tasks.

fast_forward_upgrade_role_step_tasks.yaml

This file contains a single include per role, is delegated to and only used by
the primary bootstrap node for the role as defined by
{{role.name}}BootstrapHostname.

$role/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks.yaml

These files include all fast forward upgrade tasks for a given role.

'}, {'created': '2017-11-20 14:06:43.000000000', 'message': 'WIP ffu: Add fast-forward upgrade outputs to RoleConfig

This change introduces the framework for fast-forward upgrades by adding
the following playbooks and task files as outputs to RoleConfig:

fast_forward_upgrade_playbook.yaml

This is the top level playbook controlling the upgrade. This contains a single
fast forward upgrade play that acts as the outer loop providing the release via
FastForwardUpgradeReleases to the underlying tasks.

fast_forward_upgrade_step_tasks.yaml

This file contains a single include task and is simply used to control the
inner loop providing the step to the underlying tasks.

fast_forward_upgrade_role_step_tasks.yaml

This file contains an include per role with two conditionals to ensure
that the includes are only used on a single host of a given role.

$role/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks.yaml

These files include all fast forward upgrade tasks for a given role.

bp fast-forward-upgrades

'}, {'created': '2017-11-30 13:38:34.000000000', 'message': 'ffu: Add fast-forward upgrade outputs to RoleConfig

As outlined in the spec, fast-forward upgrades aim to take an
environment from an initial release of N to a release of N>=2, beyond
that of the traditionally supported N+1 upgrade path provided today by
many OpenStack projects.

For TripleO the first phase of this upgrade will be to move the
environment to the release prior to the target release. This will be
achieved by disabling all OpenStack control plane services and then
preforming the minimum number of steps required to upgrade each service
through each release until finally reaching the target release.

This change introduces the framework for this phase of the fast-forward
upgrades by adding playbooks and task files as outputs to RoleConfig.

- fast_forward_upgrade_playbook.yaml

This is the top level play and acts as the outer loop of the process,
iterating through the required releases as set by the
FastForwardUpgradeReleases parameter for the fast-forward section of the
upgrade. This currently defaults to Ocata and Pike for Queens.

Note that this play is run against the overcloud host group and it is
currently assumed that the inventory used to run this play is provided
by the tripleo-ansible-inventory command.

- fast_forward_upgrade_release_tasks.yaml

This output simply imports the top level prep and bootstrap task files.

- fast_forward_upgrade_prep_tasks.yaml
- fast_forward_upgrade_bootstrap_tasks.yaml

These outputs act as the inner loop for the fast-forward upgrade phase,
iterating over step values while importing their associated role tasks.

As prep tasks are carried out first for each release we loop over step
values starting at 0 and ending at the defined
fast_forward_upgrade_prep_steps_max, currently 3.

Following this we then complete the bootstrap tasks for each release,
looping over steps values starting at
fast_forward_upgrade_prep_steps_max + 1 , currently 4 and ending at
fast_forward_upgrade_steps_max,currently 9.

- fast_forward_upgrade_prep_role_tasks.yaml
- fast_forward_upgrade_bootstrap_role_tasks.yaml

These outputs then finally import the fast_forward_upgrade_tasks files
generated by the FastForwardUpgradeTasks YAQL query. For prep tasks
these are always included when on an Ansible host of a given role. This
differs from bootstrap tasks that are only included for the first host
associated with a given role.

This will result in the following order of task imports with their
associated value of release and step:

'}, {'created': '2017-12-01 11:07:18.000000000', 'message': 'ffu: Add fast-forward upgrade outputs to RoleConfig

As outlined in the spec, fast-forward upgrades aim to take an
environment from an initial release of N to a release of N>=2, beyond
that of the traditionally supported N+1 upgrade path provided today by
many OpenStack projects.

For TripleO the first phase of this upgrade will be to move the
environment to the release prior to the target release. This will be
achieved by disabling all OpenStack control plane services and then
preforming the minimum number of steps required to upgrade each service
through each release until finally reaching the target release.

This change introduces the framework for this phase of the fast-forward
upgrades by adding playbooks and task files as outputs to RoleConfig.

- fast_forward_upgrade_playbook.yaml

This is the top level play and acts as the outer loop of the process,
iterating through the required releases as set by the
FastForwardUpgradeReleases parameter for the fast-forward section of the
upgrade. This currently defaults to Ocata and Pike for Queens.

Note that this play is run against the overcloud host group and it is
currently assumed that the inventory used to run this play is provided
by the tripleo-ansible-inventory command.

- fast_forward_upgrade_release_tasks.yaml

This output simply imports the top level prep and bootstrap task files.

- fast_forward_upgrade_prep_tasks.yaml
- fast_forward_upgrade_bootstrap_tasks.yaml

These outputs act as the inner loop for the fast-forward upgrade phase,
iterating over step values while importing their associated role tasks.

As prep tasks are carried out first for each release we loop over step
values starting at 0 and ending at the defined
fast_forward_upgrade_prep_steps_max, currently 3.

Following this we then complete the bootstrap tasks for each release,
looping over steps values starting at
fast_forward_upgrade_prep_steps_max + 1 , currently 4 and ending at
fast_forward_upgrade_steps_max,currently 9.

- fast_forward_upgrade_prep_role_tasks.yaml
- fast_forward_upgrade_bootstrap_role_tasks.yaml

These outputs then finally import the fast_forward_upgrade_tasks files
generated by the FastForwardUpgradeTasks YAQL query for each role. For
prep tasks these are always included when on an Ansible host of a given
role. This differs from bootstrap tasks that are only included for the
first host associated with a given role.

This will result in the following order of task imports with their
associated value of release and step:

fast_forward_upgrade_playbook
\_fast_forward_upgrade_release_tasks
  \_fast_forward_upgrade_prep_tasks              - release=ocata
     \_fast_forward_upgrade_prep_role_tasks      - release=ocata
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=0
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=0
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=1
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=1
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=2
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=2
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=3
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=3
  \_fast_forward_upgrade_bootstrap_tasks         - release=ocata
     \_fast_forward_upgrade_bootstrap_role_tasks - release=ocata
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=4
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=4
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=5
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=5
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=N
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=N
\_fast_forward_upgrade_release_tasks
  \_fast_forward_upgrade_prep_tasks              - release=pike
     \_fast_forward_upgrade_prep_role_tasks      - release=pike
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=0
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=0
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=1
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=1
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=2
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=2
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=3
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=3
   \_fast_forward_upgrade_bootstrap_tasks        - release=pike
     \_fast_forward_upgrade_bootstrap_role_tasks - release=pike
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=4
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=4
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=5
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=5
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=N
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=N

bp fast-forward-upgrades
Change-Id: Ie2683fd7b81167abe724a7b9245bf85a0a87ad1d
'}, {'created': '2017-12-07 16:47:58.000000000', 'message': 'WIP ffu: Introduce Fast Forward Upgrade tasks and playbooks

release 0
  step 0
    role 0
    role 1
  step 1
    role 0
    role 1
release 1
  step 0
    role 0
    role 1
  step 1
    role 0
    role 1

fast_forward_upgrade_playbook.yaml

This is the top level playbook controlling the upgrade. This contains a single
fast forward upgrade play that acts as the outer loop providing the release via
FastForwardUpgradeReleases to the underlying tasks.

fast_forward_upgrade_step_tasks.yaml

This file contains a single include task and is simply used to control the
inner loop providing the step to the underlying tasks.

fast_forward_upgrade_role_step_tasks.yaml

$role/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks.yaml

These files include all fast forward upgrade tasks for a given role.

Change-Id: Ie2683fd7b81167abe724a7b9245bf85a0a87ad1d

role. This differs from bootstrap tasks that are only included for the
first host associated with a given role.

This will result in the following order of task imports with their
associated value of release and step:

fast_forward_upgrade_playbook
\_fast_forward_upgrade_release_tasks
  \_fast_forward_upgrade_prep_tasks              - release=ocata
     \_fast_forward_upgrade_prep_role_tasks      - release=ocata
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=0
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=0
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=1
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=1
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=2
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=2
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=3
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=3
  \_fast_forward_upgrade_bootstrap_tasks         - release=ocata
     \_fast_forward_upgrade_bootstrap_role_tasks - release=ocata
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=4
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=4
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=5
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=5
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=N
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=N
\_fast_forward_upgrade_release_tasks
  \_fast_forward_upgrade_prep_tasks              - release=pike
     \_fast_forward_upgrade_prep_role_tasks      - release=pike
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=0
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=0
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=1
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=1
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=2
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=2
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=3
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=3
   \_fast_forward_upgrade_bootstrap_tasks        - release=pike

       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=4

'}, {'created': '2018-01-19 13:27:00.000000000', 'message': 'ffu: Add fast-forward upgrade outputs to RoleConfig

As outlined in the spec, fast-forward upgrades aim to take an
environment from an initial release of N to a release of N>=2, beyond
that of the traditionally supported N+1 upgrade path provided today by
many OpenStack projects.

For TripleO the first phase of this upgrade will be to move the
environment to the release prior to the target release. This will be
achieved by disabling all OpenStack control plane services and then
preforming the minimum number of steps required to upgrade each service
through each release until finally reaching the target release.

This change introduces the framework for this phase of the fast-forward
upgrades by adding playbooks and task files as outputs to RoleConfig.

- fast_forward_upgrade_playbook.yaml

This is the top level play and acts as the outer loop of the process,
iterating through the required releases as set by the
FastForwardUpgradeReleases parameter for the fast-forward section of the
upgrade. This currently defaults to Ocata and Pike for Queens.

Note that this play is run against the overcloud host group and it is
currently assumed that the inventory used to run this play is provided
by the tripleo-ansible-inventory command.

- fast_forward_upgrade_release_tasks.yaml

This output simply imports the top level prep and bootstrap task files.

- fast_forward_upgrade_prep_tasks.yaml
- fast_forward_upgrade_bootstrap_tasks.yaml

These outputs act as the inner loop for the fast-forward upgrade phase,
iterating over step values while importing their associated role tasks.

As prep tasks are carried out first for each release we loop over step
values starting at 0 and ending at the defined
fast_forward_upgrade_prep_steps_max, currently 3.

Following this we then complete the bootstrap tasks for each release,
looping over steps values starting at
fast_forward_upgrade_prep_steps_max + 1 , currently 4 and ending at
fast_forward_upgrade_steps_max,currently 9.

- fast_forward_upgrade_prep_role_tasks.yaml
- fast_forward_upgrade_bootstrap_role_tasks.yaml

These outputs then finally import the fast_forward_upgrade_tasks files
generated by the FastForwardUpgradeTasks YAQL query for each role. For
prep tasks these are always included when on an Ansible host of a given
role. This differs from bootstrap tasks that are only included for the
first host associated with a given role.

This will result in the following order of task imports with their
associated value of release and step:

fast_forward_upgrade_playbook
\_fast_forward_upgrade_release_tasks
  \_fast_forward_upgrade_prep_tasks              - release=ocata
     \_fast_forward_upgrade_prep_role_tasks      - release=ocata
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=0
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=0
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=1
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=1
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=2
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=2
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=3
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=3
  \_fast_forward_upgrade_bootstrap_tasks         - release=ocata
     \_fast_forward_upgrade_bootstrap_role_tasks - release=ocata
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=4
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=4
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=5
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=5
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=N
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=N
\_fast_forward_upgrade_release_tasks
  \_fast_forward_upgrade_prep_tasks              - release=pike
     \_fast_forward_upgrade_prep_role_tasks      - release=pike
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=0
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=0
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=1
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=1
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=2
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=2
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=3
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=3
   \_fast_forward_upgrade_bootstrap_tasks        - release=pike
     \_fast_forward_upgrade_bootstrap_role_tasks - release=pike
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=4
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=4
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=5
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=5
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=N
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=N

bp fast-forward-upgrades
Change-Id: Ie2683fd7b81167abe724a7b9245bf85a0a87ad1d

commit_message:
ffu: Add fast-forward upgrade outputs to RoleConfig

As outlined in the spec, fast-forward upgrades aim to take an
environment from an initial release of N to a release of N>=2, beyond
that of the traditionally supported N+1 upgrade path provided today by
many OpenStack projects.

For TripleO the first phase of this upgrade will be to move the
environment to the release prior to the target release. This will be
achieved by disabling all OpenStack control plane services and then
preforming the minimum number of steps required to upgrade each service
through each release until finally reaching the target release.

This change introduces the framework for this phase of the fast-forward
upgrades by adding playbooks and task files as outputs to RoleConfig.

- fast_forward_upgrade_playbook.yaml

This is the top level play and acts as the outer loop of the process,
iterating through the required releases as set by the
FastForwardUpgradeReleases parameter for the fast-forward section of the
upgrade. This currently defaults to Ocata and Pike for Queens.

Note that this play is run against the overcloud host group and it is
currently assumed that the inventory used to run this play is provided
by the tripleo-ansible-inventory command.

- fast_forward_upgrade_release_tasks.yaml

This output simply imports the top level prep and bootstrap task files.

- fast_forward_upgrade_prep_tasks.yaml
- fast_forward_upgrade_bootstrap_tasks.yaml

These outputs act as the inner loop for the fast-forward upgrade phase,
iterating over step values while importing their associated role tasks.

As prep tasks are carried out first for each release we loop over step
values starting at 0 and ending at the defined
fast_forward_upgrade_prep_steps_max, currently 3.

Following this we then complete the bootstrap tasks for each release,
looping over steps values starting at
fast_forward_upgrade_prep_steps_max + 1 , currently 4 and ending at
fast_forward_upgrade_steps_max,currently 9.

- fast_forward_upgrade_prep_role_tasks.yaml
- fast_forward_upgrade_bootstrap_role_tasks.yaml

These outputs then finally import the fast_forward_upgrade_tasks files
generated by the FastForwardUpgradeTasks YAQL query for each role. For
prep tasks these are always included when on an Ansible host of a given
role. This differs from bootstrap tasks that are only included for the
first host associated with a given role.

This will result in the following order of task imports with their
associated value of release and step:

fast_forward_upgrade_playbook
\_fast_forward_upgrade_release_tasks
  \_fast_forward_upgrade_prep_tasks              - release=ocata
     \_fast_forward_upgrade_prep_role_tasks      - release=ocata
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=0
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=0
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=1
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=1
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=2
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=2
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=3
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=3
  \_fast_forward_upgrade_bootstrap_tasks         - release=ocata
     \_fast_forward_upgrade_bootstrap_role_tasks - release=ocata
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=4
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=4
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=5
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=5
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=N
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=ocata, step=N
\_fast_forward_upgrade_release_tasks
  \_fast_forward_upgrade_prep_tasks              - release=pike
     \_fast_forward_upgrade_prep_role_tasks      - release=pike
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=0
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=0
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=1
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=1
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=2
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=2
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=3
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=3
   \_fast_forward_upgrade_bootstrap_tasks        - release=pike
     \_fast_forward_upgrade_bootstrap_role_tasks - release=pike
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=4
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=4
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=5
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=5
       \_$roleA/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=N
       \_$roleB/fast_forward_upgrade_tasks       - release=pike, step=N

bp fast-forward-upgrades
Change-Id: Ie2683fd7b81167abe724a7b9245bf85a0a87ad1d

(11 comments)'}, {'account_id': 12398, 'date': '2018-01-02 22:41:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-01-05 08:06:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review+1

This looks like a good first step, but can we consider switching to rendering for all roles (e.g including custom roles) by using the *.role.j2.yaml suffix?

To me that is the primary benefit, e.g supporting custom networks via j2 is great, but IMO there are far more folks already using custom roles that would benefit from rendering based on the roles_data (as well as this work to render for the network_data).'}, {'account_id': 21909, 'date': '2018-01-05 21:42:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6413, 'date': '2018-01-09 21:09:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 21909, 'date': '2018-01-09 22:03:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2018-01-10 02:03:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Code-Review+1

@shardy: Can the issues you raised be tackled in a follow-up patch?

The manila cephnfs changes targeted for queens require a new StorageNFS network and in order not to impose that on all TripleO deployments we want to make use of composable networks, hence we depend on this patch.

We have three outstanding changes under this topic that we want to merge before M3:

https://review.openstack.org/#/q/topic:bp/nfs-ganesha+(status:open+OR+status:merged)

(Note that review https://review.openstack.org/#/c/485796/ under that topic is redundant and should be abandoned.)'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-01-10 11:36:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: Code-Review+1

> @shardy: Can the issues you raised be tackled in a follow-up patch?

Sure, we could do that, but the disadvantage is that these changes aren't available for anyone that uses custom roles.

IMO it'd be much better if we could render for all roles *and* networks, without both the value of j2 rendering is diminished (e.g you could just copy/paste the existing nic config templates and modify them for custom networks, which is what all users of custom roles are going to have to do if you don't consider my feedback)."}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-01-10 11:42:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: -Code-Review

One other comment, now that there are j2.yaml files for all-the-things, the rendered versions should be removed, no?

These will be rendered as part of the plan creation, so the rendered versions should not be checked into the repo.'}, {'account_id': 12398, 'date': '2018-01-10 17:56:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

@shardy and @tbarron, I can look at generating NIC configs for all roles. It gets a little tricky, because with a custom role we have to check whether a given network is included in a role. AFAIK jinja can't check whether a string is in a list, so I have to use loops within loops to check whether a given network is in the list of role networks. It gets pretty ugly. That's one of the main reasons I wanted to do a follow-up patch to this patch, because the jinja is going to get pretty ugly, so I wanted to make it easier to review by doing incremental changes."}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-01-10 19:05:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13: Patch Set 12 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 12398, 'date': '2018-01-11 06:04:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 12398, 'date': '2018-01-11 06:04:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 12398, 'date': '2018-01-11 06:06:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

@shardy, Please have a look at the netconfig.role.j2.yaml files in each of the network/config/* directories.'}, {'account_id': 12398, 'date': '2018-01-11 06:16:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 12398, 'date': '2018-01-11 06:19:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-01-11 13:31:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

@dsneddon: thanks for the update, the netconfig.role.j2.yaml approach seems OK, although in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/532596/ I just reused the existing role.role.j2.yaml approach then special-cased the filename name for existing roles - either approach requires an update to process_templates.py and tripleo-common, so I don't have a strong preference."}, {'account_id': 12398, 'date': '2018-01-12 11:22:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 16.'}, {'account_id': 21909, 'date': '2018-01-12 20:53:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

This looks great and will really cut down on the number of example files out there and make the creation of nic files simpler.

I did find the pep8 issue with Mismatched Parameters for the VlanID<network> descriptions as described below, hence the -1.

The main question I have is with upgrades.  If customers currently have controller.yaml, compute.yal etc. local files will the upgrade be seamless and they can still use these files? They won't have to rename them to Controller-role.yaml etc?"}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-01-15 09:39:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

@Bob - see deprecated_nic_config_name in the roles_data and associated change to process_templates.py - the idea is we render the files for existing roles with the new rolename-role.yaml but also with the deprecated_nic_config_name, e.g "controller.yaml" so this should work transparently on upgrade I think (or at least that's the plan! :)'}, {'account_id': 12398, 'date': '2018-01-15 23:05:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 12398, 'date': '2018-01-16 22:55:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 17.'}, {'account_id': 12398, 'date': '2018-01-16 22:57:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 12398, 'date': '2018-01-16 23:04:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 18.'}, {'account_id': 12398, 'date': '2018-01-17 01:38:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 19.'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2018-01-18 12:26:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19:

(6 comments)

I put some remarks inline with changes to get these patches to pass pep8.

Additionally, we need to modify the StorageMgmgNetworkVlanID stanza in each of ci/environments/network/*/nic-configs/* like this:

diff --git a/ci/environments/network/multiple-nics/nic-configs/ceph-storage.yaml b/ci/environments/network/multiple-nics/nic-configs/ceph-storage.yaml
index 9c0b21c4..197db280 100644
--- a/ci/environments/network/multiple-nics/nic-configs/ceph-storage.yaml
+++ b/ci/environments/network/multiple-nics/nic-configs/ceph-storage.yaml
@@ -48,7 +48,7 @@ parameters:
     type: number
   StorageMgmtNetworkVlanID:
     default: 40
-    description: Vlan ID for the storage mgmt network traffic.
+    description: Vlan ID for the storage_mgmt network traffic.
     type: number
   TenantNetworkVlanID:
     default: 50

and we need to use name_lower in network/network.j2:

diff --git a/network/network.j2 b/network/network.j2
index 1e99de7c..70b5d344 100644
--- a/network/network.j2
+++ b/network/network.j2
@@ -68,7 +68,7 @@ parameters:
 {%- if network.vlan %}
   {{network.name}}NetworkVlanID:
     default: {{network.vlan}}
-    description: Vlan ID for the {{network.name}} network traffic.
+    description: Vlan ID for the {{network.name_lower}} network traffic.
     type: number
 {%- endif %}'}, {'account_id': 17280, 'date': '2018-01-18 16:17:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19: Code-Review-1

(5 comments)

Have not had time to review the entire patch, but some gave some feedback.'}, {'account_id': 12398, 'date': '2018-01-19 22:28:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 20.'}, {'account_id': 12398, 'date': '2018-01-19 22:32:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19:

A few questions that popped up in my mind after looking at the new roles_data.yaml and network_data.yaml:

1) How will the user specify which nic to place each network on? For example in our bare metal setups we have the ctlplane on one nic and the rest of the vlans on the 2nd nic. A user might have any number of nics and it wasn't clear from looking at the templates how this configuration is done.

2) There are a lot of parameters with names starting with "deprecated_*", for example deprecated_nic_config_name and deprecated_param_extraconfig etc... What's the meaning of these parameters?

3) How will the predictable IP feature be supported (IPs from pool)? Can you provide an example?'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2018-01-22 15:06:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 22.'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2018-01-22 15:07:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 22:

'}, {'created': '2018-01-11 06:04:12.000000000', 'message': 'Render NIC config templates with jinja2

This change converts the existing NIC templates to jinja2 in
order to dynamically render the ports and networks according
to the network_data.yaml. If networks are added to the
network_data.yaml file, parameters will be added to all
NIC templates. The YAML files (as output from jinja with
the default network_data.yaml) are present as an example.

The roles in roles_data.yaml are used to produce NIC configs
for the standard and custom composable roles. In order to
keep the ordering of NICs the same in the multiple-nics
templates, the order of networks was changed in the
network_data.yaml file. This is reflected in the network
templates, and in some of the files that is the only
change.

Note this is a work in progress. There will have to be a
sister patch to tripleo-common to implement the changes
that are made in tools/process-templates.py. Also, There
needs to be some follow-up to support legacy names of
role network configs, which do not match role names in
roles_data.yaml.

Closes-Bug: 1737041
Change-Id: I3bdb7d00dab5a023dd8b9c94c0f89f84357ae7a4
'}, {'created': '2018-01-11 06:16:35.000000000', 'message': 'Render NIC config templates with jinja2

This change converts the existing NIC templates to jinja2 in
order to dynamically render the ports and networks according
to the network_data.yaml. If networks are added to the
network_data.yaml file, parameters will be added to all
NIC templates. The YAML files (as output from jinja with
the default network_data.yaml) are present as an example.

The roles in roles_data.yaml are used to produce NIC configs
for the standard and custom composable roles. In order to
keep the ordering of NICs the same in the multiple-nics
templates, the order of networks was changed in the
network_data.yaml file. This is reflected in the network
templates, and in some of the files that is the only
change.

Note this is a work in progress. There will have to be a
sister patch to tripleo-common to implement the changes
that are made in tools/process-templates.py. Also, There
needs to be some follow-up to support legacy names of
role network configs, which do not match role names in
roles_data.yaml.

Closes-Bug: 1737041
Change-Id: I3bdb7d00dab5a023dd8b9c94c0f89f84357ae7a4

NIC templates. The YAML files (as output from jinja with
the default network_data.yaml) are present as an example.

The roles in roles_data.yaml are used to produce NIC configs
for the standard and custom composable roles. In order to
keep the ordering of NICs the same in the multiple-nics
templates, the order of networks was changed in the
network_data.yaml file. This is reflected in the network
templates, and in some of the files that is the only
change.

The roles and roles_data.yaml were modified to include
a legacy name for the NIC config templates for the
built-in roles Controller, Compute, Object Storage,
Block Storage, Ceph Storage, Compute-DPDK, and
Networker roles. There will now be a file produced
with the legacy name, but also one produced with the
<role>-role.j2.yaml format (along with environment
files to help use the new filenames).

Closes-Bug: 1737041
Change-Id: I3bdb7d00dab5a023dd8b9c94c0f89f84357ae7a4

commit_message:
Render NIC config templates with jinja2

This change converts the existing NIC templates to jinja2 in
order to dynamically render the ports and networks according
to the network_data.yaml. If networks are added to the
network_data.yaml file, parameters will be added to all
NIC templates. The YAML files (as output from jinja with
the default network_data.yaml) are present as an example.

The roles in roles_data.yaml are used to produce NIC configs
for the standard and custom composable roles. In order to
keep the ordering of NICs the same in the multiple-nics
templates, the order of networks was changed in the
network_data.yaml file. This is reflected in the network
templates, and in some of the files that is the only
change.

The roles and roles_data.yaml were modified to include
a legacy name for the NIC config templates for the
built-in roles Controller, Compute, Object Storage,
Block Storage, Ceph Storage, Compute-DPDK, and
Networker roles. There will now be a file produced
with the legacy name, but also one produced with the
<role>-role.j2.yaml format (along with environment
files to help use the new filenames).

Note this change also fixes some typos as well as
a number of templates that had VLANs with device:
entries which were ignored.

Closes-Bug: 1737041
Depends-On: I49c0245c36de3103671080fd1c8cfb3432856f35
Change-Id: I3bdb7d00dab5a023dd8b9c94c0f89f84357ae7a4

commit_message:
Move to native nodepool boot jobs

Nodepool now has a native job, switch to that

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/543268

commit_message:
Bump upstream SHAs

Bumping shas to head of stable/queens. For projects that don't
have that branch yet, a reminder was written on the same line as
the SHA.

Updates documentation to the appropriate branching.

On top of that:
- Placement API now only accepts GET, not HEAD
- Placement API now returns HTTP 200
- Designate returns the API versions under /, not under
  /versions [1]
- Cloudwatch was disabled upstream [2], so all references are
  removed.

[1]: https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/dns/
[2]: https://bugs.launchpad.net/heat/+bug/1743707

Change-Id: I29e63008bf5c3cd8ed2deb8dcd13bc6a988891f5

Fix collectstatic in case of theme customization

When doing theme customization with templates
collectstatic failes with a traceback

(cherry picked from commit dc0bce63a03e37e9f3f181930ba6d6b7c8b1346e)

[{'account_id': 21897, 'date': '2017-10-27 09:35:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 21897, 'date': '2017-10-27 09:49:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@decorators.idempotent_id('9d2e924a-baf4-11e7-b856-fa163e65f5ce')
    @testtools.skipUnless(
        compute.is_scheduler_filter_enabled("ServerGroupAffinityFilter"),
        'ServerGroupAffinityFilter is not available.')
    def test_create_server_with_scheduler_hint_group_affinity(self):
        """Tests the ServerGroupAffinityFilter
        Creates two servers in an affinity server group and
        asserts the servers are in the group and on same hosts.
        """
        group_id = self.create_test_server_group(
            policy=['affinity'])['id']
        hints = {'group': group_id}
        reservation_id = self.create_test_server(
            scheduler_hints=hints, wait_until='ACTIVE', min_count=2,
            return_reservation_id=True)['reservation_id']

        # Get the servers using the reservation_id.
        servers = self.servers_client.list_servers(
            detail=True, reservation_id=reservation_id)['servers']
        self.assertEqual(2, len(servers))

        # Assert the servers are in the group.
        server_group = self.server_groups_client.show_server_group(
            group_id)['server_group']
        hosts = {}
        for server in servers:
            self.assertIn(server['id'], server_group['members'])
            hosts[server['id']] = self._get_host(server['id'])

        # Assert the servers are on same hosts.
        hostnames = list(hosts.values())
        self.assertEqual(hostnames[0], hostnames[1],
                            'Servers are on the different host: %s' % hosts)

[root@afcbdf160084 admin]# nosetests -v test_servers_on_multinodes.py:ServersOnMultiNodesTest.test_create_server_with_scheduler_hint_group_affinity

Add compute test for ServerGroupAffinityFilter

Create two instances with the special server-group
which policy is affinity,the two instances should be
in one compute node.

Change-Id: If81e1dbba4ff8597d2f68825b7866598efd73ae7

Add functionality test case to support raid configuration.

It is a functionality test that verifies whether the raid settings
are being applied to node successfully or not.

commit_message:
Views accessible via url even if user doesn't match policy rules

When a user doesn't match the policy rules of a panel then the panel tab
is removed from the menu of the left, but panel views are still
accessible using directly the url (ex /admin/flavors/).

In most of the case, views won't work correctly because of the lack of
right in the backend, but it may cause trouble when you play with
policies.

I think it could be more elegant to return directly a "You are not
authorized to access this page" from the frontend when user try to
access a view of a panel (via url) without matching the policy rules.

Change-Id: I7bc93fed29568adfc14d5bcadfc8728d3b5cf633
Closes-Bug: #1741051
(cherry picked from commit 3f585d3b1efca1b2379d6c0a80246fd6e5a87640)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-09 13:32:28.000000000', 'message': 'Tabs in launch server wizard not depending on OPENSTACK_NOVA_EXTENSIONS_BLACKLIST

OPENSTACK_NOVA_EXTENSIONS_BLACKLIST is used to disable specific extension.
In the launch instance wizard, by example the Server Group tab should be hidden
when the extension "ServerGroups" is blacklisted but it isn't.

It could be interesting to make these tabs dependent of the supported extensions.

Change-Id: I15ea0f1010e3889c217c63e98f1752a4c1ad9ceb
Closes-Bug: #1745367
(cherry picked from commit c7bc9242b9fa416f510023f50898de1d963909c9)
'}]
commit_message:
Tabs in launch server wizard not depending on OPENSTACK_NOVA_EXTENSIONS_BLACKLIST

OPENSTACK_NOVA_EXTENSIONS_BLACKLIST is used to disable specific extension.
In the launch instance wizard, by example the Server Group tab should be hidden
when the extension "ServerGroups" is blacklisted but it isn't.

It could be interesting to make these tabs dependent of the supported extensions.

Change-Id: I15ea0f1010e3889c217c63e98f1752a4c1ad9ceb
Closes-Bug: #1745367
(cherry picked from commit c7bc9242b9fa416f510023f50898de1d963909c9)

By looking at the api-ref of other openstack projects, they don't
list the query parameters in the URL. Actually, the type of each
request's parameter has already been documented in the table so

commit_message:
api-ref: remove query parameters from URL

By looking at the api-ref of other openstack projects, they don't
list the query parameters in the URL. Actually, the type of each
request's parameter has already been documented in the table so
it is necessary to list them in URL as well. Doing that will
make the API doc looks verbose.

commit_message:
Make the apache-logs-conf role less verbose

The role is logging a lot of useless data with all the stat info
from various config and log files. Remove verbosity using no_log.

Change-Id: I72c721573ffc4a14adc3e2b29285c1071b7ec4f7

commit_message:
cyborg 0.2.0 release

Add cycle-highlight and with the latest commit

Update 1 (patch 3):
1. fix commit hash on stable/queens
2. delete unnecessary branch bump

Update 2 (patch 4):
cycle-highlight removed

update 3 (patch 5):
add tarball-base

update 4 (patch 6):
fix tarball-base

Signed-off-by: zhipengh <huangzhipeng@huawei.com>

[{'created': '2018-02-09 16:34:51.000000000', 'message': "Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/queens

The new stable upper-constraints file is only available
after the openstack/requirements repository is branched.
This will happen around the RC1 timeframe.

Recheck and merge this change once the requirements
repository has been branched.

The CI system will work with this patch before the requirements
repository is branched because zuul configues the job to run
with a local copy of the file and defaults to the master branch.
However, accepting the patch will break the test configuration
on developers' local systems, so please wait until after the
requirements repository is branched to merge the patch.

Change-Id: I6b8a80a4e6b85f11df31645003222a10de7c96c1

Change-Id: I6b8a80a4e6b85f11df31645003222a10de7c96c1

commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/queens

The new stable upper-constraints file is only available
after the openstack/requirements repository is branched.
This will happen around the RC1 timeframe.

Recheck and merge this change once the requirements
repository has been branched.

The CI system will work with this patch before the requirements
repository is branched because zuul configues the job to run
with a local copy of the file and defaults to the master branch.
However, accepting the patch will break the test configuration
on developers' local systems, so please wait until after the
requirements repository is branched to merge the patch.

Change-Id: I6b8a80a4e6b85f11df31645003222a10de7c96c1

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I415d41a9415bcbe213801af39612ba8247fd01a6

Tested the patch with directory based OSD, drive based OSD and a mix of both. Only thing i couldn't figure out was co-locating journal and OSD on the same partition/drive as the script defaults to using a directory backed journal (/var/lib/ceph/journal) if none is listed. Think that it something we can fix via a future patchset. Will continue testing, but patch seems to work good for now."}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2018-02-12 16:00:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 28.'}, {'account_id': 18476, 'date': '2018-02-12 18:31:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 28: Code-Review+1

commit_message:
Ceph: Pod per OSD via Daemonsets.

This PS extends the host targeting utility to create daemonsets
for storage focused charts. This PS supports both block device
and bind mount backed journals and OSDs.

Change-Id: Id90b197ba3e4f383eea7ce6137ed77b3ef4e5625

commit_message:
docker: use ensure_resource

... so we can have a duplicate resource in puppet-tripleo, and move
these resources to puppet-tripleo only at some point.
Right now, we can't move the resource to puppet-tripleo otherwise we
would have a duplicate resource issue.

Change-Id: I212da7757eceb8445578f2793d55c3d2bf265746

commit_message:
install-guide: Make formatting of console consistent

The formatting of the console commands is inconsistent between the
endpoint creation of the `compute` and the `placement` services. This
change reformats the commands.

Change-Id: I18f1cb8d5b3335d03e20c955c3c901b8dc1a8129

commit_message:
undercloud_deploy: add opts to setup virtual-ips

This patch wires in --control-virtual-ip and --public-virtual-ip
options that can be used to configure VIPs during the undercloud
install. Use of these options would need to be coordinated with
specific heat environments that enable the parameters we set for
this to do their job. See inline comments in this patch for
details on these environments.

Co-Authored-By: Ian Main <imain@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Ic226fdef1f5d09fbefc9fd878ed54fb82d905aef

commit_message:
Add deep merge utility to helm-toolkit

Adds "helm-toolkit.utils.merge" which is a replacement for the
upstream sprig "merge" function which didn't quite do what we
wanted, specifically it didn't merge slices, it just overrode
one with the other.  This PS also updates existing callsites
of the sprig merge with "helm-toolkit.utils.merge".

Change-Id: I456349558d4cf941d1bcb07fc76d0688b0a10782

commit_message:
Make revocation token list alwayws return 410

Since the signing options and functionality has been deprecated. The
token revocation list will not continue to work once the options
are removed. This makes the APIs return 410 (GONE) in all cases such
as if revoke_by_id is disabled (default behavior).

Change-Id: I9af8cc283d54e0cd6c3c1528f5f612bc0371189f

commit_message:
Delete system role assignments when deleting users

Keystone removes role assignments that users have on projects and
domains when deleting users. This should also apply to system role
assignments, too.

Change-Id: Ied51b9c3b58714b2d5dbcb933eca1839d1351fc7
Closes-Bug: 1749264

commit_message:
Expose bug in system assignment when deleting users

Project and domain role assignment are cleaned up when deleting
users. This commit introduces a test case that shows this isn't the
case for system role assignments. A subsequent patch will implement
a fix to make sure system role assignments are removed when users
are deleted, to be consistent with project and domain assignments.

Change-Id: I1a1e7395f462159037e939aa143e9e24aefb1841
Partial-Bug: 1749264

commit_message:
Fix missing test-requirement and cleanup docs

This patch adds oslo.serialization to the test-requirements.txt file as it is
used in some tests.
It also fixes the parameter ordering in the api-ref for the new qos parameters
on load balancers.

Change-Id: I0baf00457cb131a05b31ac83c03a7ed4a176160c

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I00cf2ae60e6290c3cb4d37ca8b9b4e4f16cdd5ea
