revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-01 22:14:24.000000000', 'message': 'Fixes missing SSL configuration for Neutron DHCP agent

Currently when deploying with TLS for internal API traffic, Neutron is
not configured to securely communicate with OVSDB.  In regular OVS agent
deployments OVS listens on ptcp and accepts any incoming connection.  In
ODL deployments OVS is configured to only listen for pssl connections.
To allow Neutron agents to communicate with OVSDB in pssl, Neutron needs
to be configured with SSL key/certificate in order to connect to OVS.

This patch adds key/certificate generation for NeutronBase service to be
consumed by any agent.  The only agent required with ODL is DHCP, so
this patch only addresses configuring SSL there.  However, a future
patch could enable SSL for default ML2/OVS agent deployments as well by
building off of this change.

Note, by default OVSDB listens on port 6640.  This does not work in ODL
deployments when ODL is on the control node because ODL also listens
on port 6640.  Therefore from the ODL service, the ovsdb_connection
setting for DHCP agent is modified when ODL is deployed.

Depends-On: I19fd9dd0c72260835eb91e557a6029ec9d652179
Depends-On: I4bbaf00f0776cab0be34d814a541fb2fd1e64326

Closes-Bug: 1746762

Change-Id: I97352027d7f750d0820610fb9e06f82b47e77056
Signed-off-by: Tim Rozet <trozet@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2018-02-01 22:16:08.000000000', 'message': 'Fixes missing SSL configuration for Neutron DHCP agent

Currently when deploying with TLS for internal API traffic, Neutron is
not configured to securely communicate with OVSDB.  In regular OVS agent
deployments OVS listens on ptcp and accepts any incoming connection.  In
ODL deployments OVS is configured to only listen for pssl connections.
To allow Neutron agents to communicate with OVSDB in pssl, Neutron needs
to be configured with SSL key/certificate in order to connect to OVS.

This patch adds key/certificate generation for NeutronBase service to be
consumed by any agent.  The only agent required with ODL is DHCP, so
this patch only addresses configuring SSL there.  However, a future
patch could enable SSL for default ML2/OVS agent deployments as well by
building off of this change.

Note, by default OVSDB listens on port 6640.  This does not work in ODL
deployments when ODL is on the control node because ODL also listens
on port 6640.  Therefore from the ODL service, the ovsdb_connection
setting for DHCP agent is modified when ODL is deployed.

commit_message:
Fixes missing SSL configuration for Neutron DHCP agent

Currently when deploying with TLS for internal API traffic, Neutron is
not configured to securely communicate with OVSDB.  In regular OVS agent
deployments OVS listens on ptcp and accepts any incoming connection.  In
ODL deployments OVS is configured to only listen for pssl connections.
To allow Neutron agents to communicate with OVSDB in pssl, Neutron needs
to be configured with SSL key/certificate in order to connect to OVS.

This patch adds key/certificate generation for NeutronBase service to be
consumed by any agent.  The only agent required with ODL is DHCP, so
this patch only addresses configuring SSL there.  However, a future
patch could enable SSL for default ML2/OVS agent deployments as well by
building off of this change.

Note, by default OVSDB listens on port 6640.  This does not work in ODL
deployments when ODL is on the control node because ODL also listens
on port 6640.  Therefore from the ODL service, the ovsdb_connection
setting for DHCP agent is modified when ODL is deployed.

Depends-On: I82281eefa1aa81207ccd8ea565cffc6ca0ec48de
Depends-On: I4bbaf00f0776cab0be34d814a541fb2fd1e64326

Closes-Bug: 1746762

Change-Id: I97352027d7f750d0820610fb9e06f82b47e77056
Signed-off-by: Tim Rozet <trozet@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: Id6cc9f40e5bb2c51ae546953fcae51a9f1b861a7

Notes to reviewers:

- I recognize that this will GET /resource_classes every time.  I'm operating on the theory that that's pretty cheap in the first place; but also probably not more expensive than PUT, which was guaranteed to happen every time for each CUSTOM resource class in the previous code.  I.e. if you've got no CUSTOM resource classes, this code makes an extra REST call.  If you've got one, it's same-same.  More than one, this is actually better.
- I experimented with some solutions that cached GET /resource_classes locally, but here there be tygers - solving them completely would require nontrivial rework up the stack (things like retries at the set_inventory_for_provider level)."}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2018-02-01 01:18:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

Agree with Jay's comments, but in general this looks good."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-02-02 13:15:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Isn' t the other way to do this to just not send any PUTs that don't start with 'CUSTOM_'?

The volume of data that is going to be retrieved by a GET /resource_classes will get bigger each time this results in creating one or more new resourced classes.

But the number of CUSTOM resource classes to be created (or verified) is small.

I guess this goes back to my belief that we should be making lots of small requests (even if redundant) rather than attempting to pre-determine changes; PUT is idempotent for a reason..."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-02-02 23:39:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(4 comments)

> The volume of data that is going to be retrieved by
> a GET /resource_classes will get bigger each time this
> results in creating one or more new resourced classes.

I was figuring the number of CUSTOM resource classes (and thus the total number of resource classes) would remain pretty small overall, so this would never be a huge burden.  That may not be a great assumption, I suppose.

> Isn' t the other way to do this to just not send any
> PUTs that don't start with 'CUSTOM_'?

Yes, but that *also* relies on the local system's notion of what the placement API expects.  This way is more future-proof in that it will continue to work if placement ever comes to accept some other prefix for consumer-creatable resource classes.

That said, the API doc explicitly dictates the CUSTOM_ prefix right now.  If the API wanted to extend that, it would have to publish a new microversion, and report client would have to make the call with that new microversion.  So we're kind of stuck with that limitation anyway.

So here's what I'm going to do: PS3 will have just the tweaks per Jay & Ed's comments; then I'll put up a PS4 that uses the CUSTOM_ logic as you suggest."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-02-02 23:39:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-02-02 23:55:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2018-02-03 00:55:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-01 00:07:09.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Ensure resource classes correctly

WIP: Real commit message
WIP: UT

Change-Id: I600ed262e1b5d11facbf461e28291193665280cf
Closes-Bug: #1746615
'}, {'created': '2018-02-01 16:07:29.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure resource classes correctly

Previously, SchedulerReportClient.set_inventory_for_provider used this
logic to pre-create custom resource classes found in the input
inventory.

        list(map(self._ensure_resource_class,
                 (rc_name for rc_name in inv_data
                  if rc_name not in fields.ResourceClass.STANDARD)))

...where _ensure_resource_class would always attempt to create the
resource class it was given, and raise an exception if that failed for
any reason.  Note in particular that attempting to create an
already-extant "standard" resource class will fail just the same as
attempting to create any nonexistent resource class that doesn't conform
to the schema (i.e. beginning with "CUSTOM_").

The problem is that this relies on the local system's notion of the set
of standard resource classes. If the placement service is running newer
code, standard resource classes may have been added that the compute
service doesn't know about yet.

This change set solves the problem by asking placement for the list of
all resource classes it knows about, and then only attempting to create
requested resource classes not in that list.

self._ensure_resource_class (which worked on a single resource class) is
replaced with self._ensure_resource_classes (plural) which accepts a
list of *all* the desired resource classes (including the standard
ones), filters out the existing ones gleaned from placement, and
attempts to create the remainder.

In the process of doing this rework, obsolete code paths relying on
pre-1.7 placement microversions are removed.

Change-Id: I600ed262e1b5d11facbf461e28291193665280cf
Closes-Bug: #1746615
'}, {'created': '2018-02-02 23:39:45.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure resource classes correctly

Previously, SchedulerReportClient.set_inventory_for_provider used this
logic to pre-create custom resource classes found in the input
inventory.

        list(map(self._ensure_resource_class,
                 (rc_name for rc_name in inv_data
                  if rc_name not in fields.ResourceClass.STANDARD)))

...where _ensure_resource_class would always attempt to create the
resource class it was given, and raise an exception if that failed for
any reason.  Note in particular that attempting to create an
already-extant "standard" resource class will fail just the same as
attempting to create any nonexistent resource class that doesn't conform
to the schema (i.e. beginning with "CUSTOM_").

The problem is that this relies on the local system's notion of the set
of standard resource classes. If the placement service is running newer
code, standard resource classes may have been added that the compute
service doesn't know about yet.

This change set solves the problem by asking placement for the list of
all resource classes it knows about, and then only attempting to create
requested resource classes not in that list.

self._ensure_resource_class (which worked on a single resource class) is
replaced with self._ensure_resource_classes (plural) which accepts a
list of *all* the desired resource classes (including the standard
ones), filters out the existing ones gleaned from placement, and
attempts to create the remainder.

In the process of doing this rework, obsolete code paths relying on
pre-1.7 placement microversions are removed.

Change-Id: I600ed262e1b5d11facbf461e28291193665280cf
Closes-Bug: #1746615

commit_message:
Ensure resource classes correctly

Previously, SchedulerReportClient.set_inventory_for_provider used this
logic to pre-create custom resource classes found in the input
inventory.

        list(map(self._ensure_resource_class,
                 (rc_name for rc_name in inv_data
                  if rc_name not in fields.ResourceClass.STANDARD)))

...where _ensure_resource_class would always attempt to create the
resource class it was given, and raise an exception if that failed for
any reason.  Note in particular that attempting to create an
already-extant "standard" resource class will fail just the same as
attempting to create any nonexistent resource class that doesn't conform
to the schema (i.e. beginning with "CUSTOM_").

The problem is that this relies on the local system's notion of the set
of standard resource classes. If the placement service is running newer
code, standard resource classes may have been added that the compute
service doesn't know about yet.

This change set solves the problem by only attempting to create resource
classes with the 'CUSTOM_' prefix.

self._ensure_resource_class (which worked on a single resource class) is
replaced with self._ensure_resource_classes (plural) which accepts a
list of *all* the desired resource classes (including the standard
ones), filters down to the CUSTOM_* ones, and attempts to create the
remainder.

Note that if placement ever decides to start allowing creation of
resource classes with prefixes other than CUSTOM_, it will have to do so
under a new microversion, so we can't future-proof this by e.g.
prefetching all the known resource classes from placement and attempting
to create any not found in that list.

In the process of doing this rework, obsolete code paths relying on
pre-1.7 placement microversions are removed.

Change-Id: I600ed262e1b5d11facbf461e28291193665280cf
Closes-Bug: #1746615

subject: Limit default workers to 8
messages: [{'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2018-02-13 22:06:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-02-13 22:10:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2018-02-13 22:11:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 5280, 'date': '2018-02-13 23:46:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1\n\n(1 comment)'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-13 22:06:17.000000000', 'message': "Limit default workers to 8

With modern servers it's not uncommon to see environments that has
dozens of logical processors. Glance defaults workers to number of
these logical processors seen by OS and each worker spins up pool
of 1000 threads. Having dozens of these thread pools consuming
resources is total overkill for most of the environments.

This change limits the amount of workers used by default to 8 which
should be plenty for most of the deployments. This limitation does
not affect if more workers is specifically configured in the config
file.

Change-Id: I6fcf2f8a416e34c0c719e1abd73f0525e686be5e
Closes-Bug: #1748916
(cherry picked from commit 6f87c7d567c9006b139b01fd1ab3bb9420fb407d)
"}]
commit_message:
Limit default workers to 8

With modern servers it's not uncommon to see environments that has
dozens of logical processors. Glance defaults workers to number of
these logical processors seen by OS and each worker spins up pool
of 1000 threads. Having dozens of these thread pools consuming
resources is total overkill for most of the environments.

This change limits the amount of workers used by default to 8 which
should be plenty for most of the deployments. This limitation does
not affect if more workers is specifically configured in the config
file.

Change-Id: I6fcf2f8a416e34c0c719e1abd73f0525e686be5e
Closes-Bug: #1748916
(cherry picked from commit 6f87c7d567c9006b139b01fd1ab3bb9420fb407d)

commit_message:
Use include_usage param in adjutant quota get view

Adjutant-ui was requesting data for all regions when
it didn't need usage for all regions. This gives us a
way to avoid that.

Change-Id: Iecb474b86c6cd1454f4eb61f7b1326bd65b1dcfa

commit_message:
Update the Tempest plugin to point towards the new plugin

The AODH service has split it's tests for Tempest in a seperate
repo so this patch updates it.  In addition, it also adds an
installation of Gnocchi as it is required for the Tempest runs
to complete.

Closes-Bug: #1747610
Depends-On: I6e9f938885036d2fabc81094e01e220b09e462dd

commit_message:
Add a param to control is we include usage in quota data

Adjutant didn't have a way to control is usage was to be included
with the quota data, and this caused perfomance issues when
adjutant-ui would query for all regions but not need the
usage data.

Change-Id: I50b6c19792ccf1a264bd29174f7d3f95180e0564

subject: Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/queens
messages: [{'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2018-02-13 18:11:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2\n\nrecheck'}, {'account_id': 10850, 'date': '2018-02-13 23:29:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-08 14:33:32.000000000', 'message': "Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/queens

The new stable upper-constraints file is only available
after the openstack/requirements repository is branched.
This will happen around the RC1 timeframe.

Recheck and merge this change once the requirements
repository has been branched.

The CI system will work with this patch before the requirements
repository is branched because zuul configues the job to run
with a local copy of the file and defaults to the master branch.
However, accepting the patch will break the test configuration
on developers' local systems, so please wait until after the
requirements repository is branched to merge the patch.

Change-Id: I90531b5f6b61a3d7b3ab82c21506e456b06855fa
"}]
commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/queens

The new stable upper-constraints file is only available
after the openstack/requirements repository is branched.
This will happen around the RC1 timeframe.

Recheck and merge this change once the requirements
repository has been branched.

The CI system will work with this patch before the requirements
repository is branched because zuul configues the job to run
with a local copy of the file and defaults to the master branch.
However, accepting the patch will break the test configuration
on developers' local systems, so please wait until after the
requirements repository is branched to merge the patch.

Change-Id: I90531b5f6b61a3d7b3ab82c21506e456b06855fa

commit_message:
Fix Redis TLS setup and its HA deployment

This patch reverts the revert of Redis TLS [1,2], and update the
pacemaker redis template to configure Redis to encrypt the
replication traffic between Redis nodes.

[1] a3769c03175cb36f0066c173477749a26f767566
[2] ebc8414cd0c18426ff80d9d65c964e91a7fe447f

Depends-On: I6cc818973fab25b4cd6f7a0d040aaa05a35c5bb1
Change-Id: I7f7be4bba6d41c04385f074857c82507cc8c2617
Closes-Bug: #1737707

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I50ea3a4f00607356a66b7d542133be26290f48a7

The CreateAndConnectCfgDrive and DeleteVOpt tasks were passing the
instance into the task.Task init as the first argument. The first arg
for the Task init is actually the task name [1]. This means that those
task names were string representations of the instance which will cause
failures if there are any non-ascii characters. This corrects the Task
init calls by removing instance as the first argument. The name kwarg
is now being used throughout the PowerVM tasks to avoid similar issues
in the future.

commit_message:
Use correct arguments in task inits

The CreateAndConnectCfgDrive and DeleteVOpt tasks were passing the
instance into the task.Task init as the first argument. The first arg
for the Task init is actually the task name [1]. This means that those
task names were string representations of the instance which will cause
failures if there are any non-ascii characters. This corrects the Task
init calls by removing instance as the first argument. The name kwarg
is now being used throughout the PowerVM tasks to avoid similar issues
in the future.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/taskflow/blob/3.1.0/taskflow/task.py#L62

Change-Id: I991a5ea33daa9a21f774fe24882ed40f990b8e0e
Closes-Bug: #1748950

Since iptables chain removal "cascades", it will remove rules
in other chains that jump to it.  Because of this, there is no

not there".

commit_message:
Fix iptables rule removal warnings from QoS extension

Since iptables chain removal "cascades", it will remove rules
in other chains that jump to it.  Because of this, there is no
need to explicitly remove these jump rules, as it will just
generate a warning of the type: "Tried to remove rule that was
not there".

Trivialfix

Change-Id: I0638562400f3bcac689d94eb2a44eae9d2890782

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I5352565c431d889e31785efd9777292b7a6847b5

messages:
[{'account_id': 27699, 'date': '2018-01-21 21:35:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-01-21 21:35:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 16513, 'date': '2018-01-22 05:29:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

This commit message is over 80 columns. 
There are 3 mariadb reviews about recovery mode include this.
Two other things are following
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/525752/
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/522729/
We'd better discuss this in IRC."}, {'account_id': 27699, 'date': '2018-01-22 14:37:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 27699, 'date': '2018-01-22 21:12:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Unfortunately I didn't see https://review.openstack.org/#/c/522729/ before submitting. I am happy with any solution that recovers if it is save and leaves things broken if there is any kind of data loss (even if auto recoverable with a loss). And I always like if errors like these include a little useful details for an OP in the logs on how to do a recovery. Eases immediately the "cluster down" panic a little.'}, {'account_id': 16513, 'date': '2018-01-23 09:44:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

How about discussing this topic at next week irc weekly meeting.
I'll post it to the meeting agenda."}, {'account_id': 8898, 'date': '2018-02-09 19:49:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 21307, 'date': '2018-02-10 15:43:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

looking forward to the discussion over IRC. while there are three ps providing various solutions, I do like additional log output providing a path for operators on how to repair the cluster. none of the other patchsets include either documentation or log information instructing the user on how to repair the cluster (if they do, I missed it).

it would be nice to see some documentation on this, outside of what we have currently at: https://docs.openstack.org/openstack-helm/latest/troubleshooting/database.html#galera-cluster'}, {'account_id': 27699, 'date': '2018-02-10 17:29:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2018-02-13 11:29:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2018-02-13 11:30:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Patch Set 4 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2018-02-13 14:50:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-21 21:35:08.000000000', 'message': 'Improve fault tolerance of MariaDB startup

* Changed podManagementPolicy to parallel in order to allow recovery from secondary or third master

	After rebooting the whole cluster on purpose or after a power failure requires a primary node the cluster can synchronize with. This is usually done automatically by selecting the node with the highest transaction id. The current implementation of the stateful set starts the nodes in sequence, preventing the start of further nodes if the process terminates with error state. Because of this, the cluster may not come up if the first or second node are not in primary state.

* Elects first node started in primary state as bootstrap source.
* Display warnings and runs mysqld with wsrep-recover on crashed nodes
* Introduces FORCE_RECOVERY argument for crash recovery

	In case the primary selection failed, the cluster bootstrap process must be manually initiated from the most advanced node (highest committed transaction id). This information is available from the grastate.dat file in case of a clean shutdown. On crashed nodes an InnoDB recovery is required to get the last committed transaction id.

	start.sh will handle both cases and gives instructions on how to recover the cluster on a hard failure. If FORCE_RECOVERY was set to the name of a POD (mariadb-0, mariadb-1, ...), the bootstrap process will be initiated from the specified node.

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: #1716461

Change-Id: I96a8cb52124f64920a7d9cf21a8924ede78ebf7b

  grastate.dat file in case of a clean shutdown. On crashed nodes an
  InnoDB recovery is required to get the last committed transaction id.

  start.sh will handle both cases and gives instructions on how to
  recover the cluster on a hard failure. If FORCE_RECOVERY was set to
  the name of a POD (mariadb-0, mariadb-1, ...), the bootstrap process
  will be initiated from the specified node.

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: #1716461

Change-Id: I96a8cb52124f64920a7d9cf21a8924ede78ebf7b
'}, {'created': '2018-02-13 11:30:26.000000000', 'message': 'Improve fault tolerance of MariaDB startup

* Changed podManagementPolicy to parallel in order to allow recovery
  from secondary or third master

  After rebooting the whole cluster on purpose or after a power failure
  a primary node the cluster can synchronize with is required. This is
  usually done automatically by selecting the node with the highest
  transaction id. The current implementation of the stateful set starts
  the nodes in sequence, preventing the start of further nodes if the
  process terminates with error state. Because of this, the cluster may
  not come up if the first or second node are not in primary state.

* Elects first node started in primary state as bootstrap source.
* Display warnings and runs mysqld with wsrep-recover on crashed nodes
* Introduces FORCE_RECOVERY argument for crash recovery

  In case the primary selection failed, the cluster bootstrap process
  must be manually initiated from the most advanced node (highest
  committed transaction id). This information is available from the
  grastate.dat file in case of a clean shutdown. On crashed nodes an
  InnoDB recovery is required to get the last committed transaction id.

  start.sh will handle both cases and gives instructions on how to
  recover the cluster on a hard failure. If FORCE_RECOVERY was set to
  the name of a POD (mariadb-0, mariadb-1, ...), the bootstrap process
  will be initiated from the specified node.

Closes-Bug: #1716461

Change-Id: I96a8cb52124f64920a7d9cf21a8924ede78ebf7b

commit_message:
Improve fault tolerance of MariaDB startup

* Changed podManagementPolicy to parallel in order to allow recovery
  from secondary or third master

  After rebooting the whole cluster on purpose or after a power failure
  a primary node the cluster can synchronize with is required. This is
  usually done automatically by selecting the node with the highest
  transaction id. The current implementation of the stateful set starts
  the nodes in sequence, preventing the start of further nodes if the
  process terminates with error state. Because of this, the cluster may
  not come up if the first or second node are not in primary state.

* Elects first node started in primary state as bootstrap source.
* Display warnings and runs mysqld with wsrep-recover on crashed nodes
* Introduces FORCE_RECOVERY argument for crash recovery

  In case the primary selection failed, the cluster bootstrap process
  must be manually initiated from the most advanced node (highest
  committed transaction id). This information is available from the
  grastate.dat file in case of a clean shutdown. On crashed nodes an
  InnoDB recovery is required to get the last committed transaction id.

  start.sh will handle both cases and gives instructions on how to
  recover the cluster on a hard failure. If FORCE_RECOVERY was set to
  the name of a POD (mariadb-0, mariadb-1, ...), the bootstrap process
  will be initiated from the specified node.

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: #1716461

Change-Id: I96a8cb52124f64920a7d9cf21a8924ede78ebf7b

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I3c7300ffdf858c81609d132fa09fab0562f08068

commit_message:
Have nl01.o.o manage min-ready of labels

Due to how multiple nodepool-launchers work today, it is possible to
have greater then min-ready of a label. To avoid this, nl01.o.o will
now be the only launcher to send min-ready requests to zookeeper.

Ideally, nodepool will be updated to support shared configuration in
the future.

Change-Id: I1cf0253343a80146f538ca5e4c83bde5c0173be3
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/queens

The new stable upper-constraints file is only available
after the openstack/requirements repository is branched.
This will happen around the RC1 timeframe.

Recheck and merge this change once the requirements
repository has been branched.

The CI system will work with this patch before the requirements
repository is branched because zuul configues the job to run
with a local copy of the file and defaults to the master branch.
However, accepting the patch will break the test configuration
on developers' local systems, so please wait until after the
requirements repository is branched to merge the patch.

Change-Id: Ie2f9c219b8b4f330e128d133a9b80ca7f254e9d4

commit_message:
Add the nova-next job to the experimental queue

The nova-next job is being moved from openstack-zuul-jobs
to the nova repo and so we'll remove it's usage from
project-config, therefore we need to define it's usage for
devstack here.

The related project-config change is:

I36d96f89b3e5323746fcbcef5cc7e4d0384a184d

Depends-On: I24a5f73c29094a23e2fdef8ee8b43601300af593
Change-Id: I28971dc7e5cb0b5cf9698e5251a7bb099e63f3db

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-02 17:00:36.000000000', 'message': 'Add generation support in aggregate association

As resource provider handling has evolved, it has become clear that
virt drivers may wish to manage a complex collection of interrelated
resource providers, resource class, traits and aggregates. Some of
those entities may be need to be managed by multiple threads of
processing, including processing in different nova-compute
processes.

The `generation` concept in the placement service providers a tool
for managing these kind of concurrent operations: a write request
that includes a generation has that generation compared against the
value on the server. If there is a match the request and can go
ahead, otherwise a ``409 Conflict`` response is returned.

This functionality is not present when associating a resource
provider with one or more aggregate uuids. For virt drivers that
wish to manage aggregate associations safely, this is necessary.
This spec describes the changes necessary to add the functionality.

Change-Id: I18b0fd3a0b2f4ddeb74182d3e79fead659894001
Blueprint: placement-aggregate-generation

commit_message:
Add generation support in aggregate association

As resource provider handling has evolved, it has become clear that
virt drivers may wish to manage a complex collection of interrelated
resource providers, resource class, traits and aggregates. Some of
those entities may need to be managed by multiple threads of
processing, including different nova-compute processes.

The `generation` concept in the placement service provides a tool
for managing these kinds of concurrent operations: a write API
request that includes a generation has that generation compared against
the value on the server. If there is a match the request can go
ahead, otherwise a ``409 Conflict`` response is returned.

This functionality is not present when associating or disassociating
a resource provider with one or more aggregate uuids. For virt drivers
that wish to manage aggregate associations safely, this is necessary.
This spec describes the changes necessary to add the functionality.

Change-Id: I18b0fd3a0b2f4ddeb74182d3e79fead659894001
Blueprint: placement-aggregate-generation

messages: [{'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-02-13 15:02:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6618, 'date': '2018-02-13 19:17:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2\n\nJulia is a stable maintenance team member, so only one +2 is needed to approve.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-13 15:02:57.000000000', 'message': 'Only set switch_id in local_link_connection if it is a mac address

When the processed lldp data is used for setting the local_link_connection
switch_id, it will set it even if the Chassis ID is not a mac.  Need to
only set it when the ChassisId is a mac address, as is done when using
non-processed lldp data.  Ironic validates that switch_id is either a
mac address or OpenFlow datapath ID.

This fixes a regresssion introduced in Pike.

Closes-Bug: 1748022
(cherry picked from commit 97282c64e97485fb40d7c64413745c74e6ead942)

commit_message:
Only set switch_id in local_link_connection if it is a mac address

When the processed lldp data is used for setting the local_link_connection
switch_id, it will set it even if the Chassis ID is not a mac.  Need to
only set it when the ChassisId is a mac address, as is done when using
non-processed lldp data.  Ironic validates that switch_id is either a
mac address or OpenFlow datapath ID.

This fixes a regresssion introduced in Pike.

Change-Id: I566acb5b19852b541df7554870ab2666f7df9614
Closes-Bug: 1748022
(cherry picked from commit 97282c64e97485fb40d7c64413745c74e6ead942)
(cherry picked from commit 9a88ac5e29847e0f38e1ed26789b31eb0c0b0f0a)

commit_message:
Only set switch_id in local_link_connection if it is a mac address

When the processed lldp data is used for setting the local_link_connection
switch_id, it will set it even if the Chassis ID is not a mac.  Need to
only set it when the ChassisId is a mac address, as is done when using
non-processed lldp data.  Ironic validates that switch_id is either a
mac address or OpenFlow datapath ID.

This fixes a regresssion introduced in Pike.

Change-Id: I566acb5b19852b541df7554870ab2666f7df9614
Closes-Bug: 1748022
(cherry picked from commit 97282c64e97485fb40d7c64413745c74e6ead942)

subject: [Fullstack] Change how DSCP marking packets are tested
messages: [{'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2018-02-02 17:22:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2018-02-05 21:42:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 4694, 'date': '2018-02-13 18:30:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-02 17:22:04.000000000', 'message': '[Fullstack] Change how DSCP marking packets are tested

In fullstack test test_dscp_marking_packets two fake hosts are
created, each of them has got one fake instance (called sender and
receiver).
Instance called "sender" sends ICMP packets to instance called
"receiver". In receiver's namespace tcpdump process is spawned with
filter to match only packets marked with specified DSCP value.
After sender instance successfully pings receiver, tcpdump process
is killed and stdout from it was examined to search logged ICMP
packets which were send from sender's IP to receiver's IP address.
That check was failing sometimes as is described in bug report.

It was failing when tcpdump doesn't capture any packets so there was
nothing on stdout from it. But even in such case tcpdump reports on
stderr summary of packets and it was like below:

0 packets captured
6 packets received by filter
0 packets dropped by kernel

which means that packets matching our filter was received by tcpdump but
were probably not processed yet. See [1] for more details.

So this patch changes filter used in tcpdump and way how its output is
checked.
Now in filter expression there are added src and dst IP addresses also so
it will match only packets send from sender instance to receiver instance.
After that tcpdump's stderr output is examined with regex to check if
line like:

X packets received by filter

is there and if X value is different than 0. If so, it means that
tcpdump received packets with wanted DSCP mark and test should pass.

[1] https://unix.stackexchange.com/a/29369

Change-Id: Ia3522237dc787edb90d162ac4a5535ff5d2a03d5
Closes-Bug: #1733649
(cherry picked from commit 386ec26b3d24f5862f6f76e0124a4370f45080cf)
'}]
commit_message:
[Fullstack] Change how DSCP marking packets are tested

In fullstack test test_dscp_marking_packets two fake hosts are
created, each of them has got one fake instance (called sender and
receiver).
Instance called "sender" sends ICMP packets to instance called
"receiver". In receiver's namespace tcpdump process is spawned with
filter to match only packets marked with specified DSCP value.
After sender instance successfully pings receiver, tcpdump process
is killed and stdout from it was examined to search logged ICMP
packets which were send from sender's IP to receiver's IP address.
That check was failing sometimes as is described in bug report.

It was failing when tcpdump doesn't capture any packets so there was
nothing on stdout from it. But even in such case tcpdump reports on
stderr summary of packets and it was like below:

0 packets captured
6 packets received by filter
0 packets dropped by kernel

which means that packets matching our filter was received by tcpdump but
were probably not processed yet. See [1] for more details.

So this patch changes filter used in tcpdump and way how its output is
checked.
Now in filter expression there are added src and dst IP addresses also so
it will match only packets send from sender instance to receiver instance.
After that tcpdump's stderr output is examined with regex to check if
line like:

X packets received by filter

is there and if X value is different than 0. If so, it means that
tcpdump received packets with wanted DSCP mark and test should pass.

[1] https://unix.stackexchange.com/a/29369

Change-Id: Ia3522237dc787edb90d162ac4a5535ff5d2a03d5
Closes-Bug: #1733649
(cherry picked from commit 386ec26b3d24f5862f6f76e0124a4370f45080cf)

subject: [Fullstack] Shutdown tcpdump process gracefully
messages: [{'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2018-02-02 17:22:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2018-02-05 21:40:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 4694, 'date': '2018-02-13 18:33:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-02 17:22:04.000000000', 'message': '[Fullstack] Shutdown tcpdump process gracefully

In fullstack test for dscp marking packets tcpdump is used to capture
packets send from one namespace (Fake VM) to another one.
When tcpdump is closed quickly with SIGKILL signal it may not displays
all packets and that might cause an issue with failed dscp marking test.

Now tcpdump will be kill with SIGINT signal so it should display
all captured packets to the stdout.
Also it should now return to stderr summary of all captured/dropped
packets which can be helpful in future debugging of issue with those
tests if that will not solve the problem.

Change-Id: Ib2d588d081a48f4f2b6e98a943bca95b9955a149
Related-Bug: #1733649
(cherry picked from commit b841a7f5d9a54468945e7eccecc91428797ebba9)
'}]
commit_message:
[Fullstack] Shutdown tcpdump process gracefully

In fullstack test for dscp marking packets tcpdump is used to capture
packets send from one namespace (Fake VM) to another one.
When tcpdump is closed quickly with SIGKILL signal it may not displays
all packets and that might cause an issue with failed dscp marking test.

Now tcpdump will be kill with SIGINT signal so it should display
all captured packets to the stdout.
Also it should now return to stderr summary of all captured/dropped
packets which can be helpful in future debugging of issue with those
tests if that will not solve the problem.

Change-Id: Ib2d588d081a48f4f2b6e98a943bca95b9955a149
Related-Bug: #1733649
(cherry picked from commit b841a7f5d9a54468945e7eccecc91428797ebba9)

[{'created': '2018-02-02 15:44:55.000000000', 'message': '[Fullstack] Shutdown tcpdump process gracefully

In fullstack test for dscp marking packets tcpdump is used to capture
packets send from one namespace (Fake VM) to another one.
When tcpdump is closed quickly with SIGKILL signal it may not displays
all packets and that might cause an issue with failed dscp marking test.

Now tcpdump will be kill with SIGINT signal so it should display
all captured packets to the stdout.
Also it should now return to stderr summary of all captured/dropped
packets which can be helpful in future debugging of issue with those
tests if that will not solve the problem.

Change-Id: Ib2d588d081a48f4f2b6e98a943bca95b9955a149

(cherry picked from commit b841a7f5d9a54468945e7eccecc91428797ebba9)
'}]
commit_message:
[Fullstack] Shutdown tcpdump process gracefully

In fullstack test for dscp marking packets tcpdump is used to capture
packets send from one namespace (Fake VM) to another one.
When tcpdump is closed quickly with SIGKILL signal it may not displays
all packets and that might cause an issue with failed dscp marking test.

Now tcpdump will be kill with SIGINT signal so it should display
all captured packets to the stdout.
Also it should now return to stderr summary of all captured/dropped
packets which can be helpful in future debugging of issue with those
tests if that will not solve the problem.

Change-Id: Ib2d588d081a48f4f2b6e98a943bca95b9955a149
Related-Bug: #1733649
(cherry picked from commit b841a7f5d9a54468945e7eccecc91428797ebba9)

commit_message:
use DVRMacAddressNotFound exception from neutron-lib

Commit I88e1aa2acf22389f69cb7d5704c80a5eb72a9bbe rehomed the
DVRMacAddressNotFound to neutron-lib. This patch consumes it by using
lib's version and removing neutron's version.

NeutronLibImpact

Change-Id: I70d1244c3bbf7664e15534e90a9d9b47e9c6e2f1

[{'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2018-01-19 18:15:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2018-01-19 18:22:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

I'm not a fan of hiding the devstack output from the live stream. BUT- that's what we've been doing, so landing this prevents us from double-logging devstack output."}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2018-01-21 11:31:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

recheck'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2018-02-02 21:45:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck log are no longer available to debug the failures.'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2018-02-02 22:09:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2018-02-05 01:27:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I agree this is wrong as is ... but ...

The logs this produces [1] aren't really what was intended for devstack-early; it's supposed to be capturing the stdout and tracing output before before we start all the fd magic to send things via log files.  [2] is actually a good example, because you'll note that we don't actually have that failure output anywhere else in the other logs of [3].

In the old days, this was capturing the output of "ansible-playbook -m shell ... stack.sh" which otherwise disappeared; now this is a task inside a bigger playbook the output is captured anyway.

You can see that in [4] where we actually have the early output captured as part of the ansible job-output.txt

Thus, I think we want to get rid of this all together

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/79/535879/2/check/devstack/d94bede/controller/logs/devstack-early.txt.gz
[2] http://logs.openstack.org/86/539686/3/check/legacy-tempest-dsvm-neutron-full-centos-7/6617c49/logs/devstack-early.txt.gz
[3] http://logs.openstack.org/86/539686/3/check/legacy-tempest-dsvm-neutron-full-centos-7/6617c49/logs/
[4] http://logs.openstack.org/79/535879/2/check/devstack/d94bede/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-02-02_22_14_14_418227'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2018-02-05 01:29:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2018-02-05 17:20:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2018-02-05 18:23:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2018-02-05 20:39:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2018-02-05 20:40:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

I agree we don't need this captured per previous comments

some irc discussion 

 - I think we should be able to save the log files with the timestamps, but avoid it for stdout, to avoid double-timestamps
 - e-r shoudl just index job-output.txt
 - we want to keep the devstack log files, because in the multinode case it's much easier to see them separately"}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2018-02-05 23:10:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6: Patch Set 5 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2018-02-09 04:28:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 1921, 'date': '2018-02-13 18:09:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

The devstack log does not show everything that is done by devstack, which was the reason always for having the devstack-early file. The port I made of that in ansible land does not work, but I think it would be worth fixing it and take the devstack log out of the job-status.

Having the devstack log in job-status may be convenient when streaming logs, but how's that going to work for multinode?"}, {'account_id': 1921, 'date': '2018-02-13 18:19:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2

I'm ok with removing this for now, we may need an alternative implementation when tackling multinode though."}]

commit_message:
Remove unneed devstack early log file

In the run devstack role we specify a path to devstack_early_log then
hand it to stack.sh as a parameter which stack.sh does nothing with.
While looking at a fix for this it was pointed out that these early logs
make it into the job's output log now so we don't need a special file
for them. Rather than handle this as a special case just let the
job-output.txt log file pick up the logs for us which allows us to
remove this unneeded feature.

Change-Id: I9bedbe91c60257d94173b1c70676dd6c2b49dc91

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: Iaf25168d669378a928e43b9a6024c7890254b70c

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-13 20:42:06.000000000', 'message': 'Include PCRE headers in bindep manifest

With the inclusion of the whereto utility in test-requirements.txt
(courtesy of change Ia14bfa6c89fd04844842d727d11ff8874ec7fc2a), tox
invocations now drag in python-pcre. Its pcremodule.c extension
needs pcre.h as provided by the libpcre3-dev package on
Debian/Ubuntu and pcre-devel on CentOS/RHEL. Note this in the
bindep.txt so that developers who may be missing it locally will
know they need to install it.

Change-Id: Iad7407a43e2db6dc9130929144e91531e26d2432
'}]
commit_message:
Include PCRE headers in bindep manifest

With the inclusion of the whereto utility in test-requirements.txt
(courtesy of change Ia14bfa6c89fd04844842d727d11ff8874ec7fc2a), tox
invocations now drag in python-pcre. Its pcremodule.c extension
needs pcre.h as provided by the libpcre3-dev package on
Debian/Ubuntu and pcre-devel on CentOS/RHEL. Note this in the
bindep.txt so that developers who may be missing it locally will
know they need to install it.

Change-Id: Iad7407a43e2db6dc9130929144e91531e26d2432

commit_message:
Non-lvm iscsi backends should run iscsid on compute and storage nodes

Cinder backends that utilize iSCSI protocol require iscsid on
compute and storage nodes to handle volumes and their backups.

Change-Id: I1c735d2abace4b46879be99731ead47d578335ea
Closes-Bug: #1725258

[{'created': '2017-09-26 07:53:58.000000000', 'message': 'Increase vm.max_map_count on elasticsearch nodes

When using newer Elasticsearch versions you will receive the following error
when trying to start: elasticsearch | max virtual memory areas
vm.max_map_count [65530] likely too low, increase to at least [262144]

This could be solved by increasing the vm.max_map_count value via sysctl.

Reference: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/vm-max-map-count.html

Change-Id: I9fa7b0222104d68bdfc838637acf5e36c479e6b2
Closes-bug: #1719528
'}]
commit_message:
Increase vm.max_map_count on elasticsearch nodes

When using newer Elasticsearch versions you will receive the following error
when trying to start: elasticsearch | max virtual memory areas
vm.max_map_count [65530] likely too low, increase to at least [262144]

This could be solved by increasing the vm.max_map_count value via sysctl.

Reference: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/vm-max-map-count.html

Change-Id: I9fa7b0222104d68bdfc838637acf5e36c479e6b2
Closes-bug: #1719528

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I924f8eb9cd5a249dd7ab1f0eda44c40a692c0bca

commit_message:
Tag the alembic migration revisions for Queens

This allows the database to be upgraded with the command:
  neutron-db-manage upgrade queens

Change-Id: I46f9b1feb0f55012e85a8d18cb5c803eacb3fd1d
(cherry picked from commit 27346e967502232a722c1a8d5888e5e503871c35)

[{'created': '2018-02-12 17:02:11.000000000', 'message': "Limit default workers to 8

With modern servers it's not uncommon to see environments that has
dozens of logical processors. Glance defaults workers to number of
these logical processors seen by OS and each worker spins up pool
of 1000 threads. Having dozens of these thread pools consuming
resources is total overkill for most of the environments.

This change limits the amount of workers used by default to 8 which
should be plenty for most of the deployments. This limitation does
not affect if more workers is specifically configured in the config
file.

Change-Id: I6fcf2f8a416e34c0c719e1abd73f0525e686be5e
Closes-Bug: #1748916

commit_message:
Limit default workers to 8

With modern servers it's not uncommon to see environments that has
dozens of logical processors. Glance defaults workers to number of
these logical processors seen by OS and each worker spins up pool
of 1000 threads. Having dozens of these thread pools consuming
resources is total overkill for most of the environments.

This change limits the amount of workers used by default to 8 which
should be plenty for most of the deployments. This limitation does
not affect if more workers is specifically configured in the config
file.

Change-Id: I6fcf2f8a416e34c0c719e1abd73f0525e686be5e
Closes-Bug: #1748916

commit_message:
Wire up pike .. queens upgrade workflow (controller only for now)

Right now the master upgrade job is running the composable steps
upgrade but that is only for Pike. For master we instead have
cli support for generating the playbooks.

See also https://review.rdoproject.org/r/#/c/11392/ /#/c/11685/

Depends-On: Ica4bb404cd3a38a97300b8af36af41c35f09825c
Change-Id: I9fbf3f454d619eae3e27ab48034e47ab767e9e14

commit_message:
Stop using deprecated running state

Ansible has deprecated the "running" state for the service module. We
need to use "started" instead.

Change-Id: I3f597a627de570d2f01d459073fc1ac334cb216d

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-18 18:26:29.000000000', 'message': "Fix ansible warning group and host with same name

Ansible warns us that our generate inventory use the same name for
a group and a host:

  [WARNING]: Found both group and host with same name: undercloud

It doesn't make much sense to have an 'undercloud' group with just the
'undercloud' host in it. Skip group creation in the generated inventory
when the group name matches the name of the sole group host.

Change-Id: I77bf3de7b2bfc7787a07d748ba28f9ff448a71ab
"}]
commit_message:
Fix ansible warning group and host with same name

Ansible warns us that our generate inventory use the same name for
a group and a host:

  [WARNING]: Found both group and host with same name: undercloud

It doesn't make much sense to have an 'undercloud' group with just the
'undercloud' host in it. Skip group creation in the generated inventory
when the group name matches the name of the sole group host.

Change-Id: I77bf3de7b2bfc7787a07d748ba28f9ff448a71ab

commit_message:
[UPDATES] Validated oc containers/images.

This change ensures that docker containers after minor update
 use docker images from file passed with --container-registry
option.

Related-Bug: 1738142

Change-Id: I926b6526d6bdc707cb88965a93709bf8514504ae

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-13 09:01:54.000000000', 'message': 'Replaces yaml.load() with yaml.safe_load()

Yaml.load() return Python object may be dangerous if you receive a YAML
document from an untrusted source such as the Internet. The function
yaml.safe_load() limits this ability to simple Python objects like integers or
lists.

Reference:
https://security.openstack.org/guidelines/ dg_avoid-dangerous-input-parsing-libraries.html

Change-Id: Ia5d9f863dc2f0193c7095769b25101b4189a05c0
'}, {'created': '2018-02-13 09:24:24.000000000', 'message': 'Replaces yaml.load() with yaml.safe_load()

Yaml.load() return Python object may be dangerous if you receive a YAML
document from an untrusted source such as the Internet. The function
yaml.safe_load() limits this ability to simple Python objects like integers or
lists.

Reference:
https://security.openstack.org/guidelines/dg_avoid-dangerous-input-parsing-libraries.html

Change-Id: Ia5d9f863dc2f0193c7095769b25101b4189a05c0
'}]
commit_message:
Replaces yaml.load() with yaml.safe_load()

Yaml.load() return Python object may be dangerous if you receive a YAML
document from an untrusted source such as the Internet. The function
yaml.safe_load() limits this ability to simple Python objects like integers or
lists.

Reference:
https://security.openstack.org/guidelines/dg_avoid-dangerous-input-parsing-libraries.html

Change-Id: Ia5d9f863dc2f0193c7095769b25101b4189a05c0

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I4da25b98e6916d36ac848201e6d964f83d9d6278

subject: Add standard attributes to l2gateway
messages:
[{'account_id': 21747, 'date': '2017-12-19 09:34:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 21747, 'date': '2017-12-19 09:57:13.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from backup to db consistency'}, {'account_id': 21747, 'date': '2017-12-19 12:08:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 21747, 'date': '2017-12-19 13:27:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 21747, 'date': '2017-12-19 13:29:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 21626, 'date': '2017-12-28 10:04:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 21626, 'date': '2017-12-28 12:22:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I need a little bit of understanding here. 

- Why are you creating migration scripts in the CONTRACT branch? As far as I understand, there is only additions of new columns for l2gateways and l2gatewayconnections tables.

- This patch only includes "standard_attr_id" but your commit msg indicated that it's also adding "created_at and updated_at". In my devstack setup, I don't see those columns and on the expand script something like this should be included:

sa.Column('created_at', sa.DateTime, nullable=False,
                  default=sa.func.now()),
        sa.Column('updated_at', sa.TIMESTAMP, server_default=sa.func.now(),
                  onupdate=sa.func.now()),

right?'}, {'account_id': 21747, 'date': '2017-12-29 00:41:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

1. According to [1], "the contract is used to store those migration rules that are not safe to apply while neutron-server is running", such as introducing or modifying constraints in this patch. And I referred to other similar Neutron patch[2], which also involves both contract and expand.
2. There is a 'standardattribute' table in neutron database, which stores the common attribute of the resources which reference it with a 
standard_attr_id. The resource items (l2gateway and l2gateway_connection) link to standard attributes table will be monitored, so its attributes like revision/created_at/updated_at will be updated automatically.  

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/pike/contributor/alembic_migrations.html
[2] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/commit/f3f90027b13a34a4c9e80e19e75ee7cdb977414d#diff-2436c70843259c4686ca15638b82bc80'}, {'account_id': 21626, 'date': '2017-12-29 11:11:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)

Should we add unit test for these db migration?
I need to test this in my local environment, but LGTM so far.'}, {'account_id': 21626, 'date': '2017-12-29 14:36:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > Should we add unit test for these db migration?
 > I need to test this in my local environment, but LGTM so far.

Should the l2-gateway-update command change the updated_at column from standardattrbs table?


| 40 | l2gateways           | 2017-12-29 12:57:36 | 2017-12-29 12:58:21 | NULL                   |               1 |                                                          
| 41 | l2gatewayconnections | 2017-12-29 12:58:21 | 2017-12-29 12:58:21 | NULL                   |               0 |                                                          
+----+----------------------+---------------------+---------------------+------------------------+-----------------+


| 40 | l2gateways           | 2017-12-29 12:57:36 | 2017-12-29 12:58:21 | NULL                   |               1 |                                                          
| 41 | l2gatewayconnections | 2017-12-29 12:58:21 | 2017-12-29 12:58:21 | NULL                   |               0 |                                                          
+----+----------------------+---------------------+---------------------+------------------------+-----------------+'}, {'account_id': 21747, 'date': '2018-01-02 07:17:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 21747, 'date': '2018-01-02 07:26:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> > (1 comment)
 > >
 > > Should we add unit test for these db migration?
 > > I need to test this in my local environment, but LGTM so far.
 > 
 > Should the l2-gateway-update command change the updated_at column
 > from standardattrbs table?
 > 
 > 
 > | 40 | l2gateways           | 2017-12-29 12:57:36 | 2017-12-29
 > 12:58:21 | NULL                   |               1 |
 > | 41 | l2gatewayconnections | 2017-12-29 12:58:21 | 2017-12-29
 > 12:58:21 | NULL                   |               0 |
 > +----+----------------------+---------------------+---------------------+------------------------+-----------------+
 > 
 > 
 > | 40 | l2gateways           | 2017-12-29 12:57:36 | 2017-12-29
 > 12:58:21 | NULL                   |               1 |
 > | 41 | l2gatewayconnections | 2017-12-29 12:58:21 | 2017-12-29
 > 12:58:21 | NULL                   |               0 |
 > +----+----------------------+---------------------+---------------------+------------------------+-----------------+

Please try this patchset. The data model of l2gateway is a 3-layers hierarchy structure. So I add the standard attribute to l2gatewaydevices tables too, since it is in the middle of the relationship between l2gwatways and l2gatewayinterfaces table.'}, {'account_id': 21747, 'date': '2018-01-02 14:21:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 21626, 'date': '2018-01-18 11:16:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2

After testing the patch in my environment, It looks good to me. It creates new entries in Neutron's standardattributes table and those are properly updated it:

| 36 | l2gateways           | 2018-01-18 11:10:45 | 2018-01-18 11:12:05 | NULL                   |               2 |
| 37 | l2gatewaydevices     | 2018-01-18 11:10:45 | 2018-01-18 11:12:05 | NULL                   |               1 |
| 38 | l2gatewayconnections | 2018-01-18 11:11:30 | 2018-01-18 11:11:30 | NULL                   |               0 |"}, {'account_id': 8313, 'date': '2018-01-18 13:43:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2018-01-20 17:30:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 21747, 'date': '2018-01-22 03:47:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9656, 'date': '2018-01-31 14:45:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

As I see it, the patch is probably fine but one may argue that adding a new field to a resource without making the feature discoverable with a new API extension is wrong.'}, {'account_id': 21626, 'date': '2018-01-31 15:05:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

> As I see it, the patch is probably fine but one may argue that
 > adding a new field to a resource without making the feature
 > discoverable with a new API extension is wrong.

As I understood, the purpose of this patch is to prepare the code to avoid db out of sync, by using revision_numbers or an approach similar to the networking-ovn team.'}, {'account_id': 9656, 'date': '2018-01-31 15:25:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> > As I see it, the patch is probably fine but one may argue that
 > > adding a new field to a resource without making the feature
 > > discoverable with a new API extension is wrong.
 > 
 > As I understood, the purpose of this patch is to prepare the code
 > to avoid db out of sync, by using revision_numbers or an approach
 > similar to the networking-ovn team.

Right. And I don't think that having the number for db sync necessarily requires you to expose new fields on api level."}, {'account_id': 26001, 'date': '2018-01-31 15:28:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 21747, 'date': '2018-02-01 09:24:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> > > As I see it, the patch is probably fine but one may argue that
 > > > adding a new field to a resource without making the feature
 > > > discoverable with a new API extension is wrong.
 > >
 > > As I understood, the purpose of this patch is to prepare the code
 > > to avoid db out of sync, by using revision_numbers or an approach
 > > similar to the networking-ovn team.
 > 
 > Right. And I don't think that having the number for db sync
 > necessarily requires you to expose new fields on api level.

Shall we merge this patch first? I'll try to expose the standard attributes in API with a new patch."}, {'account_id': 9656, 'date': '2018-02-03 02:16:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

I think you already expose those new fields, no? What is the api_collections class attribute in models if not that?'}, {'account_id': 21747, 'date': '2018-02-12 09:38:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> I think you already expose those new fields, no? What is the
 > api_collections class attribute in models if not that?

These fields ('revision_number', 'created_at', 'updated_at', 'description') will not be contained in the API response. Since l2gateway doesn't use 'NeutronRbacObject' like other neutron resources. I am wondering if we should refactor it with a new l2gateway_obj derived from NeutronRbacObject. But it looks like another big topic to this project. So I think in this patch It is better to only focus on things in DB."}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2018-02-12 10:10:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: -Code-Review

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2018-02-12 10:10:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Patch Set 6 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 21747, 'date': '2018-02-13 02:23:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Patch Set 7 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2018-02-13 05:57:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Do we want this for queens or rocky? If for queens then we need to backport it...'}, {'account_id': 21747, 'date': '2018-02-13 06:41:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

> Do we want this for queens or rocky? If for queens then we need to
 > backport it...

I think rocky is ok. This patch is just a starting point to solve the db consistency issue in the future.'}, {'account_id': 9656, 'date': '2018-02-13 18:23:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]

commit_message:
Add standard attributes to l2gateway

This adds the standard attributes to resource l2gateway and
l2gatewayconnection.

This has the advantage of providing created_at and updated_at,
however, the primary reason is to ensure it has a revision number
so it can be used to check db consistency in future.

Change-Id: I319918454a8b03ebeddb32f0528a09e5146d6e21
Signed-off-by: Peng Liu <pliu@redhat.com>

commit_message:
In mixed version upgrade we don't want yum upgrade to be triggered.

We re-use the repo-setup role during the upgrade to create the script
we push in the UpgradeInitCommand[1] command.  We don't want "yum
upgrade -y" to be triggered at that moment.

repo_setup_run_update variable enable us to do that.  We cannot
override the repo_cmd_after because it's an extra variable (passed
using "-e") and it has the highest precedence possible in ansible[2].

[1] currently there https://review.openstack.org/#/c/541621/1/playbooks/multinode-overcloud-upgrade.yml
[2] https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/playbooks_variables.html#variable-precedence-where-should-i-put-a-variable

Change-Id: I4b2f2696d366db766a5ab146cc718ccc4a15c629

commit_message:
Add name to debug tasks

This makes it clearer that the previous task failed, which isn't
immediately evident from the ansible task output due to the failed_when
on those tasks.

Change-Id: I765208d5865f6e5a292e5b52c572e2e79540c663
Closes-Bug: #1748443

commit_message:
Add a playbook for publishing javascript tarballs

The publish-openstack-javascript-content job specifies
`playbooks/javascript/publish.yaml` as a post-run playbook,
but this playbook doesn't exist. This commit adds this
missing playbook, which fetches the javascript output and
tarball for publishing to tarballs.o.o.

Change-Id: I6c0ad5e2e0d35f3d331e4dd18edca79a4649b79a

commit_message:
Refactor stackviz run

Refactor the stackviz run into _copy_devstack_files.  For
devstack-only, this will run once, but for grenade it will run twice
and put the old & new results into the same global data directory.

Change-Id: Ic27943fcc09685b589e2925c3ca7cbda52b41c27

commit_message:
Fix devstack subunit output

In I00847bb6733febf105855ae6fc577a7c904ec4b4 we changed things so DEST
was actually obeyed for things like SUBUNIT_OUTPUT.  This highlighted
that devstack-gate is looking in the wrong place for the devstack
subunit output file.  It should be picking it up from the [old|new]
directory.

Closes-Bug: #1617476
Change-Id: Idd59953b29db41c69121504288f4d727d800b666

commit_message:
Refactor devstack log copying

This introduces a single function to collect devstack logs.  It either
runs once for the devstack case, or twice (once for "old" and once for
"new") in the grenade case.  I've rolled the duplicated parts of the
code, including the testr artificat stuff, into this single function.

The layout is simplified into three distinct phases

1) copy devstack files
2) copy generic system logs/status
3) cleanup & compression

I feel this makes the whole process much easier to understand (even
with greatly increased comments diffstat is ~equal), reduces
duplication and reduces the chance that we make mistakes when trying
to introduce various log processing enhancements.

Change-Id: I1a2220a5a9d729a619ee2137d3566c3d09f5e3b4

commit_message:
Invalid query parameter could lead to HTTP 500

Invalid query parameter could lead to HTTP 500, although
Nova used JSON Schema verification to check input query
params, but query like: GET /servers?limit=%88 will still
lead to HTTP 500, as it failed to parse at webob which is
pre JSON Schema check.

Partial-Bug: #1746202

Change-Id: I11b94a1aaeb67dc1a5abdcf0af5961ee8942a50a

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

* Modifies ``glance manage db sync`` operation to use
  expand, migrate and contract operations.

    # Uses Alembic batch operations to perform the temporary table
      dance for sqlite.

      the rows are fetched. So, changed the data migrate script to
      fetch rows in order determine whether there are pending
      migrations

* Removes monolith migration for Ocata

commit_message:
Modify glance manage db sync to use EMC

Modified 'glance-manage db_sync' operation to use
expand, migrate and contract operations.
Added test queens scripts for testing purpose only.

This patch removes use of "monolithic" upgrade scripts
and resolve the issue while upgrading from ocata to pike.

Co-Authored-By: Shilpa Devharakar <Shilpa.Devharakar@nttdata.com>
Closes-Bug: #1723001

Change-Id: I2653560d637a6696f936b49e87f16326fd601dfe

commit_message:
Drop neutronclient-specific cliff sphinx extension

Previously neutronclient has its own variant of cliff sphinx
extension to support cliff app autodocument (cliff-app directive).
The feature has been implemented in cliff 2.10.0.
This patch switches to the cliff official version.

The cliff official version also contains several nice fixes
around the sphinx extension.

Change-Id: If542fdf88ef57ec3ce8ecc017127b5dc194e6c9a

commit_message:
Change the check method for the ceph ods version

Previously, the ceph version was checked with "ceph -v".
However, this way is only check for the ceph client version.
So I change the way to check the ceph osd version.

Change-Id: I11f44186f671594e6e9e848f3fddb1d23b994b36

commit_message:
prep-image: pass http-boot only for containerized undercloud

Until we figure out a better way of managing http-boot argument when
preparing the image, let's add a conditional so we only use it for a
containerized undercloud and not for the OVB jobs which seems to not
work as of today.

Change-Id: Ia8fdfd0e26a88ec8f9a3840983538fc6bc3de96f
Related-Bug: #1748921

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I241b59af506ea91a3267a73ed5ca2d509a68406a

messages: [{'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2018-02-05 21:11:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2018-02-13 00:15:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 4162, 'date': '2018-02-13 16:24:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-05 21:11:13.000000000', 'message': "Check for virtualenv binary

The current check looks for a virtualenv package; but this isn't
portable to other platforms.  In the gate we also have installed from
upstream (to ensure latest) and the package might be on hold, etc
which might mess up the detection.

I think the KISS thing to do is to check for virtualenv and fail with
a useful message.

Change-Id: Icf15ddd18ca52885f5c4a89a7d83622a70c811d5
"}]
commit_message:
Check for virtualenv binary

The current check looks for a virtualenv package; but this isn't
portable to other platforms.  In the gate we also have installed from
upstream (to ensure latest) and the package might be on hold, etc
which might mess up the detection.

I think the KISS thing to do is to check for virtualenv and fail with
a useful message.

commit_message:
[Fullstack] Unmark test_dscp_marking_packets as unstable

Bug 1733649 is now closed with patch
Ia3522237dc787edb90d162ac4a5535ff5d2a03d5

This commit removes decorator which marked fullstack test
test_qos.TestDscpMarkingQoSOvs.test_dscp_marking_packets
as unstable.

This commit removes also some additional logs of tcpdump's
output added only as temporary "debug" solution.

Change-Id: I0343b1b4fd8d6eed1c26838bf70bce9868e6ee0c
Related-Bug: #1733649

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: If9bef5ae884bfefadc06752b3ca140ac2e91399d

commit_message:
Install proper virtualenv package for RH OS

This commit adds support for installing virtualenv on CentOS or Fedora,
as otherwise it'll fail due to the name difference (virtualenv =>
python-virtualenv)

Besides the solution proposed at [1] this would ensure it will not fail
for Centos nor Fedora.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/541010

Change-Id: I21e270aecb9fbef08ee2bc436d1d49952be8b57d

commit_message:
Workaround reboot issue in Octavia hm interface template

The health manager port fails to start on reboot if the ONBOOT line
appears after the longish OVS_EXTRA line.

Closes-Bug: #1746742

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-05 22:12:05.000000000', 'message': "Query all cells for service version in _validate_bdm

We call _validate_bdm during instance creation to validate block device
mappings boot indexes, accessibility, attachability, and so on. We need
to query the service version in order to decide which Cinder APIs to
call and because we're in the middle of creating the instance, we
don't yet know which cell it's going to land in.

This changes the service version query to check all cells so that
_validate_bdm will use the 'reserve_volume' Cinder API in a multi-cell
environment. Use of the 'reserve_volume' API is based on the service
version check and without targeting any cells, the service version will
be 0 and we'll use the old 'check_attach' API.

Conflicts:
      nova/tests/unit/compute/test_compute_api.py

NOTE(mriedem): Conflicts are due to not having change
Ifc01dbf98545104c998ab96f65ff8623a6db0f28 in Pike which added
a test and updated some other tests which we now have to do
in this change.

Closes-Bug: #1746634

Change-Id: I68d5398d2a6d85c833e46ce682672008dbd5c4c1
(cherry picked from commit 0258cecaca88d4a305e99c5a17e2230361ef1235)
"}]
commit_message:
Query all cells for service version in _validate_bdm

We call _validate_bdm during instance creation to validate block device
mappings boot indexes, accessibility, attachability, and so on. We need
to query the service version in order to decide which Cinder APIs to
call and because we're in the middle of creating the instance, we
don't yet know which cell it's going to land in.

This changes the service version query to check all cells so that
_validate_bdm will use the 'reserve_volume' Cinder API in a multi-cell
environment. Use of the 'reserve_volume' API is based on the service
version check and without targeting any cells, the service version will
be 0 and we'll use the old 'check_attach' API.

Conflicts:
      nova/tests/unit/compute/test_compute_api.py

NOTE(mriedem): Conflicts are due to not having change
Ifc01dbf98545104c998ab96f65ff8623a6db0f28 in Pike which added
a test and updated some other tests which we now have to do
in this change.

Closes-Bug: #1746634

Change-Id: I68d5398d2a6d85c833e46ce682672008dbd5c4c1
(cherry picked from commit 0258cecaca88d4a305e99c5a17e2230361ef1235)

commit_message:
Use ceph-admin-keyring to execute storage_init script in Cinder.

Like a glance, gnocchi, ceph-admin-keyring script should be needed when
execute storage_init.sh in cinder.

Change-Id: I5ab1b474de7cc0a9f80642502d74d1d1f156dea5
Closes-bug: 1744207

[{'created': '2018-02-13 06:17:49.000000000', 'message': 'Replaces yaml.load() with yaml.safe_load()

Yaml.load() return Python object may be dangerous if you receive a YAML
document from an untrusted source such as the Internet. The function
yaml.safe_load() limits this ability to simple Python objects like integers or
lists.

Reference:
https://security.openstack.org/guidelines/ dg_avoid-dangerous-input-parsing-libraries.html

Change-Id: Ifc5c911170c6d173c3ab8f387a63d5089c0aac13

Yaml.load() return Python object may be dangerous if you receive a YAML
document from an untrusted source such as the Internet. The function
yaml.safe_load() limits this ability to simple Python objects like integers or
lists.

Reference:
https://security.openstack.org/guidelines/dg_avoid-dangerous-input-parsing-libraries.html

commit_message:
Replaces yaml.load() with yaml.safe_load()

Yaml.load() return Python object may be dangerous if you receive a YAML
document from an untrusted source such as the Internet. The function
yaml.safe_load() limits this ability to simple Python objects like integers or
lists.

Reference:
https://security.openstack.org/guidelines/dg_avoid-dangerous-input-parsing-libraries.html

Change-Id: Ifc5c911170c6d173c3ab8f387a63d5089c0aac13

commit_message:
[UPDATES] Validated oc containers/images.

This change ensures that docker containers after minor update
 use docker images from file passed with --container-registry
option.

Related-Bug: 1738142

Change-Id: I926b6526d6bdc707cb88965a93709bf8514504ae

commit_message:
Fix hardcoded dependency for ExtraConfigPost.

Remove the hardcoded value to the right variable.  Note you need the
-1 because the loop is done with jinja ‘range’ function which goes from
(start, finish-1)[1].

[1] http://jinja.pocoo.org/docs/2.10/templates/#range

Change-Id: I01c8d2521c0ee249b94e9cdc1b895da1523c50a3

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-25 09:30:31.000000000', 'message': 'Make eventlet hub use a monotonic clock

If system time is adjusted first forward and then backward while a
nova service is running (e.g. nova-compute), then there is a high
probability, that periodic tasks will stop for the duration of time
the system clock was adjusted backward.

This was supposed to be fixed by the following patch to oslo.service
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/286838/ , but the order of imports
in unit tests and production code is different, so nova services
end up starting with the default eventlet hub, that does not use a
monotonic clock and, thus, is affected by changes of system time.

Testing this is problematic, as it's a subject of imports order and
is not reproduced in functional or unit tests (oslo_service is always
imported earlier than eventlet hub is initialized, so it just does
"the right thing"). The alternative is to make an assertion when
services start.

Closes-Bug: #1510234

Change-Id: I110cf31ad2a0c74a0cf30ec08bd94d3a56727b39
'}, {'created': '2018-01-26 10:12:58.000000000', 'message': 'Make eventlet hub use a monotonic clock
